revision.text:
[[File:Affinity wall.png|thumb|Affinity wall diagram]] The '''affinity diagram''' is a business tool used to organize ideas and data. It is one of the [[Seven Management and Planning Tools]]. People have been grouping data into groups based on natural relationships for thousands of years; however, the term affinity diagram was devised by [[Jiro Kawakita]] in the 1960s<ref>Improving Performance Through Statistical Thinking By Galen C. Britz</ref> and is sometimes referred to as the '''KJ Method'''.
The tool is commonly used within [[project management]] and allows large numbers of ideas stemming from [[brainstorming]]<ref>[http://www.pmhut.com/affinity-diagram-kawakita-jiro-or-kj-method Affinity Diagram - Kawakita Jiro or KJ Method], Retrieved June 6, 2010</ref> to be sorted into groups, based on their natural relationships, for review and analysis.<ref>[http://www.leanyourcompany.com/methods/Using-Affinity-Diagrams.asp Using Affinity Diagrams to make sense from brainstorming]</ref> It is also frequently used in [[contextual inquiry]] as a way to organize notes and insights from field interviews. It can also be used for organizing other freeform comments, such as open-ended survey responses, support call logs, or other qualitative data.
==Process== The affinity diagram organizes ideas with following steps: # Record each idea on cards or notes. # Look for ideas that seem to be related. # Sort cards into groups until all cards have been used.
Once the cards have been sorted into groups the team may sort large clusters into subgroups for easier management and analysis.<ref>Value: Its Measurement, Design and Management By M. Larry Shillito</ref> Once completed, the affinity diagram may be used to create a [[Ishikawa diagram|cause and effect diagram]].<ref>[http://www.tin.nhs.uk/index.asp?pgid=1129 NHS Improvement network]</ref>
In many cases, the best results tend to be achieved when the activity is completed by a cross-functional team, including key stakeholders. The process requires becoming deeply immersed in the data, which has benefits beyond the tangible deliverables.
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{Group creativity techniques}} ==External links== {{Commonscat|Affinity diagrams}} * [http://memosort.co/ Memosort - Online tool for collaborative affinity diagramming] * [http://www.discover6sigma.org/d6slab/affinity/ Online AFFINITY tool at Discover 6 Sigma Lab]
[[Category:Business terms]] [[Category:Usability]]

revision.text:
{{arabic name|Bin Sulayem}} {{Infobox person | name = Ahmed Sultan Bin Sulayem | image = Ahmed Sultan Bin Sulayem, 2010.jpg | caption = Ahmed Sultan Bin Sulayem addresses delegates at 7th City of Gold Conference | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1978|03|13}} | birth_place = [[Dubai]] | occupation = Executive Chairman of the [[Dubai Multi Commodities Centre]] Authority (DMCC) | years_active = 2001–present | residence = [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]] | alma_mater = [[California State University]], [[San Bernardino, California]] | website = {{URL|https://www.dmcc.ae/about-us/executive-chairman|www.dmcc.ae/about-us/executive-chairman}} }}
'''Ahmed Sultan Bin Sulayem''' (Arabic: أحمد سلطان بن سليّم) is the Executive Chairman of DMCC ([[Dubai Multi Commodities Centre|Dubai Multi Commodities Centre)]],<ref name="dmcc.ae">{{cite web|url=http://www.dmcc.ae |title=DMCC |publisher=dmcc.ae |date= |accessdate=2011-08-17| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110719200809/http://www.dmcc.ae/| archivedate=19 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl=no}}</ref> the free zone authority in [[Jumeirah Lakes Towers|Jumeirah Lakes Towers (JLT)]]<ref name="jlt.ae">{{cite web|url=http://www.jlt.ae |website=www.jlt.ae |title=Community portal |accessdate=2011-08-17}}</ref> and established in 2002 by the Government of Dubai to provide the physical, market and financial infrastructure required to establish the emirate as a hub for global commodities trade.<ref>{{cite web|author=Dubai Government |url=http://www.dubai.ae |title=dubai.ae |publisher=dubai.ae |date= |accessdate=2011-08-17| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110722143645/http://www.dubai.ae/| archivedate= 22 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> He is the son of [[Sultan Ahmed bin Sulayem]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=SPI Group|title=Failures, not success stories, biggest source of learning -|url=http://www.theintelligentsme.com/2013/12/failures-not-success-stories-biggest-source-of-learning/|website=The Intelligent SME|accessdate=9 July 2017|date=29 December 2013}}</ref> As of September 2018, DMCC had over 15,000 registered members operating within it's free zone including commodities, businesses as well as other sectors.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.zawya.com/mena/en/story/DMCC_signs_UN_womens_empowerment_principles_advancing_gender_equality-ZAWYA20180307114551/|title=DMCC signs UN women's empowerment principles advancing gender equality|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=2018-09-22|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ameinfo.com/dubai-multi-commodities-centres-continuous-growth-348108 |title=Dubai Multi Commodities Centre's continuous growth sets the stage for major expansion |date=July 9, 2013 |website=www.ameinfo.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130714015217/http://ameinfo.com/dubai-multi-commodities-centres-continuous-growth-348108 |archivedate=July 14, 2013 }}</ref> In 2018, Bin Sulayem completed 17 years with DMCC.
== Career == As the Executive Chairman of DMCC, Bin Sulayem has played a key role in establishing and positioning DMCC as a major commodities trade hub in the region. Under his leadership, DMCC has introduced a number of value-added products and services; including the establishment of the Dubai Diamond Exchange (DDE),<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/diamond/dubai-diamond-exchange/ |title=Dubai Diamond Exchange |website=dmcc.ae |date= |accessdate=2011-08-17 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526225927/http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/diamond/dubai-diamond-exchange/ |archivedate=May 26, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> the only diamond exchange in the Arab World affiliated to the [[World Federation of Diamond Bourses]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wfdb.com/ |title=World Federation of Diamond Bourses |website=wfdb.com |date=2011-07-14 |accessdate=2011-08-17| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110718034839/http://wfdb.com/| archivedate= 18 July 2011 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Dubai Tea Trading Centre (DTTC)<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|url=http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/tea/dubai-tea-trading-centre/ |title=Dubai Tea Trading Centre |publisher=dmcc.ae |date= |accessdate=2011-08-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711154915/http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/tea/dubai-tea-trading-centre/ |archivedate=2011-07-11 |df= }}</ref> which offers a range of value-added facilities to the global tea trade and has contributed to the UAE becoming the world's largest re-exporter of tea;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gulfmanagers.com/news-3749-it-s-my-cup-of-tea.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-10-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131009070548/http://www.gulfmanagers.com/news-3749-it-s-my-cup-of-tea.html |archivedate=2013-10-09 |df= }}</ref> DMCC Tradeflow,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/tradeflow/ |title=Tradeflow |website=dmcc.ae |accessdate=2012-10-06 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120920054612/http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/tradeflow/ |archivedate=2012-09-20 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> a central registry of ownership for commodities stored in Dubai stimulating commodity trade by offering enforceable collateral based trade finance solutions; as well as other services, such as gold refineries, gold and diamond vaults; as well as the UAE gold bullion coins<ref name="www.uaegoldbullioncoins.ae">{{cite web|url=http://www.uaegoldbullioncoins.ae|title=UAE Gold Bullion Coins - DMCC |website=www.uaegoldbullioncoins.ae}}</ref> and the Visions of Dubai<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/gold/visions-of-dubai/ |title=Visions of Dubai |website=dmcc.ae |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111224011445/http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/gold/visions-of-dubai/ |archivedate=2011-12-24 |accessdate=2011-08-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> gold souvenir coins.
Bin Sulayem joined DMCC in 2001 as a director, prior to the official launch of the entity in 2002, and his responsibilities included overseeing the organisation’s operations. In addition to his responsibilities as Executive Chairman Bin Sulayem also serves as the Director of Human Resources, Director of Dubai Shariah Asset Management (DSAM) and Dubai Commodity Asset Management (DCAM).<ref name="autogenerated3">{{cite web|url=http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/financialservices/asset-management/ |title=Asset management |website=dmcc.ae |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001065400/http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/financialservices/asset-management/ |archivedate=October 1, 2011 |accessdate=2011-08-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
He has also played a leading role in reviving Dubai’s traditional pearling industry by launching the Dubai Pearl Exchange<ref name="autogenerated4">{{cite web|url=http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/pearl/dubai-pearl-exchange/ |title=Dubai Pearl Exchange |website=dmcc.ae |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120327190753/http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/pearl/dubai-pearl-exchange/ |archivedate=March 27, 2012 |accessdate=2011-08-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> in 2007 and conceptualizing the design of Almas Tower, the tallest commercial building in the Middle East, home to Dubai Diamond Exchange, one of the largest vaults in the UAE,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/gold/dmcc-gold-vault/ |title=DMCC gold vault |website=dmcc.ae |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120327190805/http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/gold/dmcc-gold-vault/ |archivedate=March 27, 2012 |accessdate=2011-08-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> and DMCC headquarters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ameinfo.com/dmccs-ahmed-bin-sulayem-announces-plans-347465 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130707193032/http://www.ameinfo.com/dmccs-ahmed-bin-sulayem-announces-plans-347465 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-07-07 |title=DMCC's Ahmed Bin Sulayem announces plans to build world's tallest commercial tower |website=www.ameinfo.com |df= }}</ref> [[File:ASBS0002.jpg|thumb| Ahmed Sultan Bin Sulayem presents Vision of Dubai Coin to H. H Sheikh [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum]]]]
[[File:3) DGCX Launch - Nov -'05 009.jpg|thumb| Ahmed Sultan Bin Sulayem during DGCX Launch with H. H Sheikh [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum]]]] [[File:ASBS0008.jpg|thumb| Ahmed Sultan Bin Sulayem during [[Almas Tower]] Ground Breaking in 2005]]
In April 2011, DMCC hosted the World Federation of Diamond Bourse's annual Presidents' meeting, an initiative spearheaded by Bin Sulayem. This event was the first of its kind to be held in the Arab world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/diamond/news/news-details/222/ |title=Former South African President Mbeki: UAE has successfully developed into one of the major players in the diamond industry |website=dmcc.ae |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929062226/http://www.dmcc.ae/jltauthority/diamond/news/news-details/222/ |archivedate=September 29, 2011 |accessdate=2011-08-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In addition, on August 15, 2011, Bin Sulayem unveiled the prototype of the UAE's first gold bullion coin. The coin recognises the visionary leadership of [[Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan|His Highness Sheikh Khalifa Bin Zayed Al Nahyan]], President of the [[United Arab Emirates]] and [[His Highness Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum]], Vice President, Prime Minister and Ruler of Dubai. Designed by DMCC, the “Khalifa” coin features a portrait of His Highness [[Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan|Sheikh Khalifa]] on one side, and on the other, [[Burj Khalifa]], the world’s tallest tower.
Following the announcement of its first gold UAE bullion coin in August 2011, on 2 December 2011, DMCC released the first design impressions of the second UAE bullion coin as part of DMCC’s celebration of the 40th anniversary of the UAE and in recognition of His Highness Sheikh Mohammed Bin Rashid Al Maktoum, Vice President of the UAE and Ruler of Dubai. Titled “Palm Jumeirah”, the gold coin features a portrait of His Highness Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum on one side, and on the other, an image of the iconic Palm Jumeirah. The coin is the second in a series and follows the “Burj Khalifa” coin which was successfully launched last August, and paid tribute to His Highness Sheikh Khalifa Bin Zayed Al Nahyan, President of the UAE.<ref name="www.uaegoldbullioncoins.ae"/>
In June 2012, Bin Sulayem received UN accreditation to represent Western Asia on behalf of [[CIBJO]], the international jewellery confederation of national trade organisations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zawya.com/story/United_Nations_accreditation_for_Ahmed_bin_Sulayem-ZAWYA20120714060044/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130210004407/http://www.zawya.com/story/United_Nations_accreditation_for_Ahmed_bin_Sulayem-ZAWYA20120714060044/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-02-10 |title=United Nations accreditation for Ahmed bin Sulayem |website=www.zawya.com |subscription=yes}}</ref> CIBJO has been a consultative member of ECOSOC, the United Nations Economic and Social Council, since 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.diamonds.net/News/NewsItem.aspx?ArticleID=40588&ArticleTitle=CIBJO+President+Addresses+ECOSOC+in+NY|title=CIBJO President Addresses ECOSOC in NY|website= www.diamonds.net |date=July 11, 2012}}</ref> ECOSOC is one of the largest agencies operating under the United Nations umbrella, and is a coalition involving government, civil society and the business community.<ref>{{cite web|title=The World Jewellery Confederation|url=http://www.cibjo.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=235&Itemid=46|website=www.cibjo.org|accessdate=April 15, 2017}}</ref>
In June 2013, he received the [[Crowe Horwath]] Award for 'Government Personality of the Year.<ref name="mubasher">{{cite web|url=http://english.mubasher.info/DFM/news/2347757/Bin-Sulayem-receives-Horwath-Mak-Award-for-Government-Personality-of-the-Year|title=Bin Sulayem receives Horwath Mak Award for Government Personality of the Year|date=June 13, 2013 |website=english.mubasher.info}}</ref> This was presented to Bin Sulayem for his role in the expansion of the global commodities sector; his commitment towards establishing Dubai as the global gateway to trade; [[Dubai Multi Commodities Centre|DMCC’s]] contribution to Dubai’s economy through the over 7,400 companies operating from its free zone; his efforts in developing Dubai’s Islamic Finance sector through pioneering products and services; and his social and philanthropic work focused on society, culture and heritage.
Also in June 2013, Bin Sulayem became recognised as a prominent fan of the [[LA Lakers]] due to the full page advertisement he took out in the [[LA Times]] paying tribute to [[Kobe Bryant]]. The ad thanked [[Kobe Bryant]] for his contributions to the [[LA Lakers]] and wished him a speedy recovery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lakersnation.com/fan-takes-out-full-page-l-a-times-ad-thanking-kobe-bryant/2013/06/09/|title=Fan Takes Out Full-Page L.A. Times Ad Thanking Kobe Bryant|author=Daniel Buerge|date=9 June 2013|work=Lakers Nation}}</ref> In September 2013, Bin Sulayem hosted [[Kobe Bryant|Kobe Bryant's]] first trip to the UAE as part of the DMCC Kobe Bryant Health and Fitness Weekend <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeoutdubai.com/sportandoutdoor/events/26211#.UlUFftLHdRI|title=DMCC presents the Kobe Bryant Health & Fitness Weekend Celebrity Basketball Game|work=Time Out Dubai}}</ref> where he also presented Bryant with a DMCC Free Zone license.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gulfbusiness.com/2013/09/nba-champion-bryant-receives-tax-free-trade-licence-in-dubai/|title=NBA Champion Kobe Bryant To Open Health Business In Dubai|work=Gulf Business|author=Mary Sophia|date=26 September 2013}}</ref>
In December 2015, Bin Sulayem was appointed chair of the [[Kimberley Process Certification Scheme]] for a one-year term.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenational.ae/business/dmcc-chief-ahmed-bin-sulayem-to-lead-fight-against-conflict-diamonds-1.106452|title=DMCC chief Ahmed bin Sulayem to lead fight against ‘conflict diamonds’|last=|first=|date=|work=The National|access-date=2018-09-22|language=en}}</ref>
In addition to his role at DMCC, Bin Sulayem is also Chairman of the Dubai Diamond Exchange, which is a DMCC platform.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.diamonds.net/News/NewsItem.aspx?ArticleID=59436&ArticleTitle=Peter+Meeus+to+Leave+Dubai+Exchange|title=Diamonds.net - Peter Meeus to Leave Dubai Exchange|last=|first=|date=|website=www.diamonds.net|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-22}}</ref> Bin Sulayem is also the Chairman of the [[Dubai Gold & Commodities Exchange]] (DGCX),<ref name="dgcx.ae">{{cite web|title=Board of Directors » Dubai Gold & Commodities Exchange|url=https://www.dgcx.ae/board-of-directors|website=www.dgcx.ae|accessdate=April 15, 2017}}</ref> which is a DMCC platform.
== Education == Bachelor’s degree in Business Administration, [[California State University]] – San Bernardino, 2000.
== Timeline == * 2001: Director, Pre-Implementation DMCC Authority. * May 2002: Chief Operating Officer, DMCC * February 2006 Vice President, DDE * July 2006 - May 2009: General Manager, JLT * May 2007: Executive Chairman, DMCC * June 2007: Director Seven Tides International * September 2007: Director: Seven Tides Limited * November 2007, Chairman, DGCX * March 2008: Director, DCAM and DSAM * April 2011: HR Director and Executive Chairman, DMCC * June 2012: UN accreditation to represent Western Asia on behalf of CIBJO * June 2013: Government Personality of the Year award by Crowe Horwath * January 2014: Outstanding Contribution to Islamic Finance Award, Mena Fund Manager Performance Awards *December 2015: Chair of the Kimberley Process Certification Scheme.
== Awards and honours== * Honoured by the New York Diamond Dealers Club (DDC) in 2006 as part of its 75th anniversary celebrations for contributing to the global diamond industry.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sundaram|first1=Anjan|title=Jewish Diamonds Find Favor in Arab Dubai - washingtonpost.com|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/10/22/AR2006102200293_pf.html|website=www.washingtonpost.com|accessdate=15 April 2017|date=October 22, 2006}}</ref> * Received Middle East Investor Award at the Hedge Funds World Middle East Conference 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=DMCC Executive Chairman Receives ’Middle East Investor Award’ At Hedge Funds World Middle East Conference - Middle East Events|url=http://www.middleeastevents.com/news/page/dmcc-executive-chairman-receives-rsquomiddle-east-investor-awardrsquo-at-hedge-funds-world-middle-east-conference/9178|website=www.middleeastevents.com|accessdate=15 April 2017}}</ref> *Government Personality of the Year award by Crowe Horwath - June 2013{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} *Outstanding Contribution to Islamic Finance Award, Mena Fund Manager Performance Awards - January 2014<ref>{{cite web|title=UAE Minister of Economy Presents DMCC's Ahmed Bin Sulayem With Award for Outstanding Contribution to Islamic Finance|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/uae-minister-of-economy-presents-dmccs-ahmed-bin-sulayem-with-award-for-outstanding-contribution-to-islamic-finance-240146831.html|website=www.prnewswire.com|accessdate=15 April 2017|language=en}}</ref> *Outstanding Contribution of the Year Award, Jewellery News Asia, September 2014<ref>{{cite web|title=Industry leaders take home trophies at 2014 JNA Awards - JNA|url=http://www.jewellerynewsasia.com/DetailPages/ArticleContentPage?WEBONID=11024|website=www.jewellerynewsasia.com|accessdate=April 15, 2017}}</ref> *Honoured by the Diamond Dealers Club of New York, December 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.idexonline.com/FullArticle?Id=42732|title=KP Chair Bin Sulayem Honored by Diamond Dealers Club of New York|last=|first=|date=|website=www.idexonline.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-22}}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Ahmed Sultan Bin Sulayem during Gold Bullion coin launch.jpg|Ahmed Sultan Bin Sulayem during Gold Bullion coin launch File:ASBS0004.jpg|Ahmed Sultan Bin Sulayem presents Dubai Cut Diamond to H. H Sheikh [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum]] File:DSAM Kauthar.jpg|DSAM Kauthar Gold Fund Receives the Outstanding Performance and Innovation Award File:DMCC KOBE LA TIMES AD.jpg|DMCC Kobe LA Times Ad </gallery>
==See also== *[[Dubai Multi Commodities Centre]] *[[Jumeirah Lakes Towers]] *[[Dubai Gold & Commodities Exchange]]

revision.text:
[[File:Airbus A310-304 'CS-TKI' (13611108175).jpg|thumb|[[Airbus A310]] being dismantled at [[Pinal Airpark]]]]
'''Aircraft recycling''' is the [[recycling industry]] of [[aircraft]].
==Market==
Each year, 400 to 450 aircraft are scrapped and disassembled globally, for a $2 billion market for aircraft parts, and 12,500 aircraft will reach their end-of-life in the 20 years after 2009.<!--<ref name=ATEMoct2009/>--> Of those, around one third are parted out and disassembled by members of the [[Aircraft Fleet Recycling Association|AFRA]].<ref name=ATEMoct2009>{{cite article |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110722040613/https://afraassociation.org/NewsDocs/09_OctNov_ATE_M.pdf |title= Aircraft recycling best practice and the role of AFRA |magazine= Aircraft Technology Engineering & Maintenance |date= October 2009 |pages= 30-37 }}</ref> The AFRA is an international non-profit association aiming to promote environmental [[best practice]]s, regulatory excellence and sustainable developments in the fields of aircraft disassembly, as well as the salvaging and recycling aircraft parts and materials.
Retirements peaked at more than 700 in 2013 and declined to about 500 in 2016 while strong demand and relatively low fuel prices keep older airliners flying, the in-service aircraft older than 15 years grew by more than 1,600 between 2013 and 2017.<!--<ref name=Flight5mar2018/>--> As part prices were high in early 2018, some young, 15–20 years old A319 and A320s are being parted out.<!--<ref name=Flight5mar2018/>--> Decommissions should rise to 750 annually, 3,900 from 2018 through 2022, while manufacturers plan to ramp up deliveries to 2,200 aircraft in 2020.<ref name=Flight5mar2018>{{cite news |url= https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/analysis-aircraft-retirement-wave-poses-challenges-446179/ |title= Aircraft retirement wave poses challenges for recyclers |date= 5 March 2018 |author= Michael Gubisch |work= Flightglobal}}</ref>
== Storage statistics ==
Lessor [[Avolon]] count 2,100 aircraft are in storage in 2017 with 1,000 which shouldn't fly again: half are parked for more than three years and the other half is older than 25 years.<!--<ref name=MRO6nov2017/>--> A parked airplane may return to service if it's younger than 15 and aircraft parked over three years have a 50% chance of flying again, dropping to 20% for aircraft stored over five years.<!--<ref name=MRO6nov2017/>--> With owners accepting their assets value, this 2,100 should remain constant as the global jet transport fleet doubles to 51,800 over the next 20 years with 43,000 new deliveries and 16,000 retirements projected through 2037.<ref name=MRO6nov2017>{{cite news |url= http://www.mro-network.com/fleet/old-birds |title= Old Birds |at= Smarter end-of-life strategies will cut into storage figures, Avolon says. |author= Lee Ann Shay |date= Nov 6, 2017 |work= Aviation Week Network}}</ref>
==Process== [[File:IL-86 RA-86095 Scissor cockpit. (3121102935).jpg|thumb|[[Ilyushin Il-86]] cut at [[Sheremetyevo Airport]]]]
Airliners are typically operated for 20 to 30 years.<ref>{{Cite news |title = Aircraft Recycling |url = http://www.aviationpros.com/article/10874310/aircraft-recycling |date = 28 February 2013 |author= Charles Chandler |work= AviationPros |publisher= [[Cygnus Business Media]]}}</ref> [[Corrosion]], [[metal fatigue]], and low availability of new spare parts are problems encountered in greater frequency the older a machine becomes. Eventually, these factors, alongside improvements in fuel-efficiency and reduction in maintenance cost of newer machines, reduce the economical viability of the operation of older airliners. Consequently, they may be stored, or scrapped and recycled.
<!-- storage --> Vast expanses of arid desert are ideal for storage because hangars are not needed to maintain the aircraft at low humidity. Upon arrival, aircraft are washed to remove corroding salt, drained of fuel and lubricated with a light viscous oil. Explosive devices from the [[evacuation slide]]s are removed, air ducts sealed, and an easily removable protective coat of paint may be applied.<ref name=BBC18sep2014>{{Cite news |title = The secrets of the desert aircraft 'boneyards' |url= http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20140918-secrets-of-the-aircraft-boneyards |publisher= BBC |author= Stephen Dowling| date = 18 September 2014}}</ref> Some airliners are kept in working order as reserves, and a few are involved in fire-fighting and aerospace training schemes or in safety tests.<ref name=BaselNov2006>{{Cite web |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20161018043030/http://www.grida.no/files/publications/vital-waste2/VWG2_p3to46.pdf |title= Vital Waste Graphics 2 |date= November 2006 |publisher= The Basel Convention Secretariat |author= Claudia Heberlein |page= 30}}</ref>
Most are used as source of spare parts and scrapped. The scrapping process takes six weeks and begins with the removal of the explosive escape equipment and toxic de-icing fluid. Some components are unbolted and salvaged, including the engines and instruments, while the fuel is drained away.<ref name=AvWeek1Feb2006>{{Cite news |title= Recycling Aircraft |date= 1 Feb 2006 |work= Aviation Week |author= Bill Burchell |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120223114843/http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_generic.jsp?channel=om&id=news%2Fom206pam.xml <!-- subscription required: http://aviationweek.com/awin/pamela-project--> }}</ref>
The seats are worth from $450 to $5,000 and the [[landing gear]] can be sold for millions of dollars, although all parts need a Certificate of Airworthiness to be re-used. Cables, batteries and other [[electronic waste]] are fed into the conventional recycling chains. The remaining shell is cut into pieces and broken down by an [[industrial shredder]] so that the aluminium can be melted down.<ref>{{Cite news |title= Where Old Airplanes Go to Die |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/28/business/28iht-wbscrap.html |newspaper= The New York Times |date= March 28, 2009 |issn= 0362-4331 |author= Caroline Brothers}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title= How To Recycle An Airplane |url= http://jalopnik.com/5569874/how-to-recycle-an-airplane/ |author= Matt Hardigree |date= 22 June 2010 |website = [[Jalopnik]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title= How do you recycle a jumbo jet? |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8542482.stm |publisher= BBC |date= 10 March 2010 |author= Mario Cacciottolo}}</ref>
The scrap metal is ground up, mechanically sorted by density and magnetism, then sold to the trade. A future challenge for disposal is the construction of aircraft which use composite materials, such as aluminium/fibreglass [[GLARE]] in the [[Airbus A380]].<ref name=BaselNov2006/> There are also concerns about contamination with alloys and the dumping of non-recyclable materials.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://users.ox.ac.uk/~pgrant/Airplane%20scrapping%20and%20recycling.pdf |title= Aircraft Scrapping and Recycling |date= 28 Nov 2007 |publisher= Boeing Commercial Airplanes |work= Airplane Environmental Performance |author= Bill Carberry}}</ref>
[[File:N951AR McDonnell Douglas MD-11F Skylease Cargo (8754546592).jpg|thumb|[[McDonnell Douglas MD-11]] part out]]
An airliner can be dismantled in 1,500-2,000 parts (1,000 or so [[Line-replaceable unit|LRU]]s) in 30–60 days including engines, landing gear, auxiliary power units and components but it can be parked a year or two to maximise the part harvesting.<!--<ref name=Flight5mar2018/>--> A metal aircraft can be recycled up to 85-90% by mass with a 95% goal, and 85-90% could be maintained for composite airframes as the industry adapts with a carbonfibre market growing 12-14% a year towards 100,000t in 2019 of which 50% could be satisfied with recycled material.<ref name=Flight5mar2018/>
== Places ==
The [[Davis–Monthan Air Force Base]] in Arizona is home to 4,400 retired aircraft, chiefly military, and the [[Mojave Air and Space Port]] stores over 1000 civilian planes.<ref name=BBC18sep2014/> Purpose-built recycling platforms may be used, such as those of Bartin Aero Recycling at [[Châteauroux-Centre "Marcel Dassault" Airport|Châteauroux-Déols airport]] in France, Air Salvage International at [[Cotswold Airport]], UK, and the Evergreen Aircenter, in Marana, US. [[Airbus]] has set up a centre in [[Tarbes–Lourdes–Pyrénées Airport|Tarbes Airport]] in France to research the decommission and recycling of older aircraft as part of the [[PAMELA Project]].<ref name=AvWeek1Feb2006/>
==See also==
* [[Aircraft boneyard]] * [[Aircraft Fleet Recycling Association]] * [[Airliner]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Disassembled aircraft}}
* {{cite video |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ycZZT5K4a-M |title= Boeing 777 Special Disassembly |date= Nov 6, 2017 |quote= special disassembly of a Boeing 777 airframe from just behind the wings to the tail |author= Jet Yard |publisher= Aviation Week Network}} * {{cite news |url= http://www.mro-network.com/maintenance-repair-overhaul/airbus-safran-suez-see-future-aircraft-recycling |title= Airbus, Safran, Suez See Future In Aircraft Recycling |at= Aircraft recycling likely to remain profitable, despite increasing retirements and environmental challenges. |author= Thierry Dubois |date= Dec 7, 2017 |publisher= Aviation Week Network}} * {{cite news |url= https://www.ainonline.com/aviation-news/business-aviation/2017-12-26/end-line-bizjets-beer-cans |title= End of the Line: Bizjets to Beer Cans |author= Curt Epstein |date= December 26, 2017 |work= AIN}}

{{Multiple issues|{{copy edit|date=October 2018}}{{lead rewrite|date=October 2018|reason=Lead does not effectively summarize, article}}}} {{short description|Conglomerate based in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia}} {{Infobox company | name = Al Bayan Holding Group Limited
مجموعة البيان القابضة | logo = [[File:Logo_of_Al_Bayan_Holding_Group.jpg|400px]]| type = [[Conglomerate (company)|Conglomerate]]| industry = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | founded = {{Start date and age|1980}} | founder = | defunct = | hq_location_city = [[Riyadh]] | hq_location_country =[[Saudi Arabia]] | area_served = [[Saudi Arabia]] [[Kuwait]]| key_people = [[Abdul Rahman Al Hammad|Dr. Abdul Rahman Obeid Abdulrahman Al Hammad]], Co-Owner (24.5%){{Cite web|url=https://www.decypha.com/en/people-list/Abdulrahman-Al-Hammad-165148|title=Abdulrahman Obeid Abdulrahman Al Hammad {{!}} Saudi Arabia {{!}} Decypha|website=www.decypha.com|access-date=2018-09-21}}, (CEO) Nasser Al Hammad (Co-Owner) Sultan Al Hammad (Co-Owner)| products = | owner = | num_employees = | num_employees_year = | parent = | website = {{URL|www.albayan.com.sa}} }} '''Al Bayan Holding Group''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]: '''مجموعة البيان القابضة''') is a [[Conglomerate (company)|group of companies]] and one of the [[List of companies in Saudi Arabia|leading businesses]] based in [[Riyadh]], [[Saudi Arabia]] and in [[Kuwait City]], [[Kuwait]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.kuwaitlocal.com/business/bayan-holding-company-kuwait-city|title=Kuwait Local {{!}} Bayan Holding Company - Kuwait City|last=Technologies|first=Mano|website=www.kuwaitlocal.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-18}}. According to ''[[Reuters]]'', in 2013, it became the first Saudi Arabian company to issue an Islamic bond in [[Malaysian ringgit]]{{Cite news|url=https://in.reuters.com/article/saudi-sukuk-ringgit-idINL6N0DB3HS20130424|title=Al Bayan issues first ringgit sukuk from Saudi firm|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=IN|access-date=2018-09-16|language=en-IN}}. The same news was also published by ''[[Saudi Gazette]]''{{Cite news|url=http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/article/42062/First-Saudi-firm-issues-sukuk-in-Malaysia|title=First Saudi firm issues sukuk in Malaysia|date=2013-04-24|work=Saudigazette|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en-GB}}. As part of the 1 billion [[Malaysian ringgit]] investment programme, Al Bayan kicked off the deal by pumping 200 million [[Malaysian ringgit]]. The Company, through its subsidiaries, provides services including real estate development and management, information and telecommunications, printing and packaging, logistics, and supply and trading{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/profiles/companies/0611569D:AB-al-bayan-holding-group|title=Al Bayan Holding Group|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-09-16}}. In 2016, [[Bahrain|Bahrain's]] ''[[Trade Arabia]]'' reported that [[Spain|Spain's]] [[Telepizza]] signed off a franchisee deal with Al Bayan Holding Group in order to establish one of three [[Saudi Arabia|Kingdom's]] branches in [[Riyadh]]. In 2014, Al Bayan Holding Group signed a $70 million syndicated Islamic term financing facility with a group of leading regional and international banks{{Cite web|url=http://tradearabia.com/touch/article/BANK/250390|title=Al Bayan signs $70m Islamic finance facility|website=tradearabia.com|access-date=2018-09-16}}. In 2012, ''[[Asharq Al-Awsat]]'' informed that [[Abdul Rahman Al Hammad|Dr. Al Hammad]] was operating 20 companies in [[Saudi Arabia]] and in [[Gulf Cooperation Council]]{{Cite web|url=http://archive.aawsat.com/details.asp?issueno=8800&article=150109#.W6JzwNDhXqD|title=شركة البيان القابضة تطرح استراتيجيات عمل لمؤسسات القطاع الخاص لتحقيق أهدافها,|website=archive.aawsat.com|access-date=2018-09-19}}, including Aloula Geojit Company{{Cite web|url=http://www.aloulageojit.net/page.php?id=7&l=2|title=Aloula Geojit|website=www.aloulageojit.net|access-date=2018-09-21}}. ==Achievements== In 2005, ''[[Al Riyadh (newspaper)|Al Riyadh]]'' reported that Al Bayan Holding Group's Chairman [[Abdul Rahman Al Hammad|Dr. Abdul Rahman Al Hammad]] signed a commercial advertising deal with Minister [[Iyad bin Amin Madani]] of [[Ministry of Culture and Information (Saudi Arabia)|Minister of Culture and Information]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.alriyadh.com/76316|title=«البيان» تحتكر إعلانات التلفزيون السعودي بـ 228 مليون ريال|work=جريدة الرياض|access-date=2018-10-01|language=ar}}. In 2012, ''[[Al Riyadh (newspaper)|Al-Riyadh]]'' reported that the administration of [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|King Abdullah Al Saud]] officially granted Al Bayan Holding Group to organize the annual [[Jenadriyah|Al Jenadriyah]] festival in [[Riyadh]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.alriyadh.com/712144|title=خادم الحرمين يكرم «مجموعة البيان القابضة» لرعايتها مهرجان الجنادرية|work=جريدة الرياض|access-date=2018-09-18|language=ar}}. In 2013, ''[[Al Jazirah (newspaper)|Al Jazirah]]'' reported that the then Governor of [[Riyadh]], [[Khalid bin Bandar Al Saud|Prince Khalid bin Bandar bin Abdulaziz Al Saud]], awarded Dr. Al Hammad for the excellent work done by DNGO Contracting Company, one of the entitites of Al Bayan Holding Group for implementing the project of strengthening of water resources in Riyadh{{Cite web|url=http://www.al-jazirah.com/2013/20130430/ln1.htm|title=بمناسبة تكريم سمو أمير الرياض لمجموعة البيان القابضة|website=www.al-jazirah.com|access-date=2018-09-18}}. === Al Hammad as Vice Chairman of Saudi Cooperative Societies Council=== In 2015, ''[[Saudi Gazette]]'' reported that [[Abdul Rahman Al Hammad|Dr. Al Hammad]] was appointed as the new Vice Chairman of [[Cooperative Societies Council|Saudi Cooperative Societies Council]] on 22 November 2014{{Cite news|url=http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/article/145172|title=Al-Hammad urges creation of more Saudi cooperative societies|date=2015-12-24|work=Saudigazette|access-date=2018-09-18|language=en-GB}} by [[Saud Bin Salman bin Abdulaziz al Saud|Prince Saud bin Salman bin Abdulaziz al Saud]]. However, the incumbency of Dr. Al Hammad's position is disputed after the 2017 crisis when [[Malaysia|Malaysia's]] [[RAM Holdings Berhad|RAM]] suspended Al Bayan Holding Group's ratings. ===Major Contracts=== In 2014, [[Hilton Hotels & Resorts]] signed a deal with Al Bayan Holding Group's Dar Al Bayan Real Estate firm in order to launch a hotel in [[Jubail]], [[Saudi Arabia]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.hospitalitynet.org/news/4051491.html|title=Hilton Worldwide Signs First Hilton Hotels & Resorts Property In Al Jubail, Saudi Arabia|last=Net|first=Hospitality|website=Hospitality Net|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-18}}. ==2017 Crisis== In March 2017, [[Malaysia|Malaysia's]] ''[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]'' reported that [[Malaysia|Malaysian]] [[RAM Holdings Berhad|RAM Rating Services]] of RAM Holdings Berhad, [[Kuala Lumpur]] suspended the rating of the RM1bil Sukuk Wakalah (2013/2023) issued by Al Bayan Holding Company following the group’s failure to meet certain obligations under RAM’s rating mandate. This resulted the escalation of Al Bayan's financial crisis{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/business/business-news/2017/03/07/ram-ratings-suspends-rating-of-al-bayan-rm1b-sukuk/|title=RAM Ratings suspends rating of Al Bayan's RM1b Sukuk - Business News {{!}} The Star Online|website=www.thestar.com.my|access-date=2018-09-18}}. {{quote|“We were unable to contact Al Bayan and seek a satisfactory resolution of outstanding matters.”  ― RAM}} After the suspension of RAM ratings, it was reported that many firms started to withdrew their contracts and agreements with Al Bayan Holding Group, indicating that there is a financial crisis undergoing in Al Bayan. ===2017 Anti-Corruption Drive=== It was reported that the [[Government of Saudi Arabia|Saudi government]] arrested co-owners of Al Bayan Holding Group in November 2017, including [[Abdul Rahman Al Hammad|Dr. Abdul Rahman Al Hammad]], following [[Muhammad bin Salman|Crown Prince Muhammad bin Salman's]] launch of [[2017 Saudi Arabian purge|2017 Anti-Corruption Drive]]. However, these suspicions and allegations didn't appeared in the local press of [[Saudi Arabia]]. ===Social Media Outrage=== In December 2017, an Egyptian expatriate calling himself as an employee of Al Bayan Holding Group uploaded a video on YouTube where he explained about his mental harassment in the firm via the four co-owners. He also requested the arrest of co-owners and clearance of his dues through intervention of [[Salman of Saudi Arabia|King Salman Al Saud]]{{Citation|last=Medhat Bogee|title=استغاثة العاملين بشركة مجموعة البيان القابضة بالرياض|date=2017-11-27|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LFPMCereqxI&feature=youtu.be|access-date=2018-09-18}}The same person uploaded a video in late December 2017 or early January 2018 where he records a footage through his mobile phone in which he shows a group of stranded employees of DNGO Contracting Company and Nahdaat Al Emaar, the two subsidiaries of Al Bayan Holding Group without their dues and salaries calling for justice{{Citation|last=Medhat Bogee|title=تكملة للاستغاثة للعاملين بشركة مجموعة البيان القابضة دونجو ونهضة الاعمار للمقاولات|date=2017-11-28|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oTP92l44gsI&feature=youtu.be|access-date=2018-09-19}}. In early January 2017, an person informing himself as an engineer assigned at Al Bayan Holding Group recorded a footage via his mobile phone and later uploaded it on [[YouTube]]. In the video, he had shown that employees holding banners are on strike against the firm as some of them didn't receive their dues and salaries from the past 13 months{{Citation|last=Engr.Sherief.Ahmed|title=اعتصام موظفين مجموعة البيان القابضة بادارة الشركة بالعليا والشركة تطلب الشرطة للموظفين|date=2018-01-09|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=youtu.be&v=cCq1BJq1THg&app=desktop|access-date=2018-09-18}}. The same engineer uploaded a video in the same month of January where he shows stranded expatriates who didn't received their salaries for more than six months on strike against the firm at the Al Bayan's project site in [['Asir Region]]{{Citation|last=Engr.Sherief.Ahmed|title=اعتصام عمال مجموعة البيان القابضة مشاريع عسير|date=2018-01-09|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GmqBYoqoR5M|access-date=2018-09-21}}. An another expatriate in Al Bayan Holding Group uploaded a video on YouTube in February 2018 requesting justice from [[Salman of Saudi Arabia|King Salman Al Saud]] and [[Muhammad bin Salman|Crown Prince Muhammad bin Salman Al Saud]] after he didn't received his salary for more than 12 months{{Citation|last=hamada Mostafa|title=مجموعه البيان القابضه للمقاولات وتأخر رواتب سنه كامله|date=2018-02-03|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ytAbDfOMuso&feature=youtu.be|access-date=2018-09-18}}. [[Category:1980 establishments in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Companies of Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Conglomerate companies of Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Business organisations based in Saudi Arabia]] ==References== __INDEX__ __NEWSECTIONLINK__

{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=August 2012}} {{BLP sources|date=December 2013}} }} {{Infobox person | name = Andrei Korobeinik | image = RE Andrei Korobeinik.jpg | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1980|11|5|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Pärnu]], [[Estonia]] | nationality = [[Estonia]]n | known_for = [http://www.rate.ee www.rate.ee], [http://www.cutefund.com www.cutefund.com], [http://www.flirtic.com www.flirtic.com] | occupation = [[Programmer]], [[Investor]], [[Entrepreneur]] }}
'''Andrei Korobeinik''' (born 5 November 1980) is an [[Estonia]]n [[Programmer|computer programmer]] and entrepreneur, founder and CEO of Rate Solutions<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ratesolutions.eu/ |title=Rate Solutions | Home |publisher=Ratesolutions.eu |date= |accessdate=2013-12-06}}</ref> and Serenda Invest. He is better known as creator of Estonian social networking site, Rate.ee.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.rate.ee/ |title=Rate Solutions LLC; pildid, sõbrad, tutvus |publisher=Rate.ee |date= |accessdate=2013-12-06}}</ref> Between 2011 and 2013 he was a member of the [[Riigikogu|Estonian parliament]].
In 2005, 51% share of the Rate.ee portal was sold to [[EMT (mobile operator)|EMT]] for 39 million [[Estonian kroon|Estonian Krones]] (approximately 2 million [[EURO]]), making Andrei one of the youngest [[Estonia]]n [[millionaires]] of that time. However, in 2012 Serenda Invest; a company that manages Rate.ee was purchased back from [[EMT (mobile operator)|EMT]] which essentially put Andrei back in charge of his [[web portal]]. The price of this deal has not been revealed.
Korobeinik is the winner of 2008 British Council's International Young Interactive Entrepreneur Award. He is the member of Estonian Dragon's Den jury and does angel investments, mostly into internet start-ups.
Korobeinik has been on the jury at the annual Estonian TV show Ajujaht.<ref>[http://www.estban.ee/news/article Interview with Andrei Korobeinik on angel investing]</ref>
==Education== Korobeinik graduated from Pärnu Russian Gymnasium in 1998, same year he started with his undergraduate studies at [[University of Tartu]] in maths and information technology.
==Other business ventures== In 2010, he started a new project Cutefund.com.<ref>[http://heaeestiidee.blogspot.com/2010/07/andrei-korobeinik-loob-toelist-rahva.html Andrei Korobeinik loob tõelist „rahva investeerimsifondi“]</ref> Cutefund.com is a crowdsourced mutual fund, designed to buy and sell stock on behalf of investors. Cutefund.com is currently awaiting for a license to trade stock, until then users can register and compete with each other for free in demo mode. Korobeinik is the author of idea for Flirtic.com,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flirtic.com/ |title=social network for flirting and meeting new people! |publisher=Flirtic.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-06}}</ref> a dating website popular in [[Eastern Europe]] and [[Russia]].
==Political career== In the [[Estonian parliamentary election, 2011]], Korobeinik ran for [[Riigikogu]] membership for [[Pärnu County]]. He got 2057 votes but did not make it to the Parliament. He became a member of the [[Riigikogu|Estonian Parliament]] starting on 6 April 2011, replacing [[Rein Lang]] who went to serve as the Minister of Culture of Estonia. When Lang step down on December 4, 2013, Korobeinik lost his place in the Parliament. Korobeinik was a chairman of e-parliament committee.
==Hobbies== He is a chess player, and on 20 November 2011 was elected as president of Estonian Chess Union.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://serenda.com/ Serenda.com] * [http://uudised.err.ee/index.php?06250991 Uudised.err.ee] * [http://www.director.ee/ainult-1-kusimus-andrei-korobeinik/ Director.ee]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Korobeinik, Andrei}} [[Category:1980 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the Riigikogu]] [[Category:Estonian Reform Party politicians]] [[Category:Estonian businesspeople]] [[Category:Estonian computer programmers]] [[Category:Estonian people of Russian descent]]

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Autarchism}} {{Economic systems sidebar|By coordination}} '''Autarky''' is the [[quality (philosophy)|quality]] of being [[Self-sufficiency|self-sufficient]]; the term is usually applied to political states or their [[economic system]]s. Autarky exists whenever an entity can survive or continue its activities without external assistance or [[international trade]]. If a self-sufficient [[economy]] also ''refuses'' all trade with the outside world then it is called a '''closed economy'''.<ref>[http://www-personal.umich.edu/~alandear/glossary/c.html#ClosedEconomy|Deardorff's Glossary of International Economics] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071212072813/http://www-personal.umich.edu/~alandear/glossary/c.html |date=2007-12-12 }}.</ref> The term "closed economy" is also used technically as an abstraction to allow consideration of a single economy without taking foreign trade into account – i.e. as the antonym of [[open economy]]. Autarky in the political sense is not necessarily an economic phenomenon; for example, a [[military]] autarky would be a state that could defend itself without help from another country, or could manufacture all of its weapons without any imports from the outside world.
Autarky as an ideal or method has been embraced by a wide range of [[political ideologies]] and [[Civil rights movements|movements]], especially [[Left-wing politics|left-wing]] creeds like [[African socialism]], [[Mutualism (economic theory)|mutualism]], [[council communism]], [[syndicalism]] (especially [[anarcho-syndicalism]]) and [[Left-wing populism|leftist populism]]. It has also been used in temporary, limited ways by [[Conservatism|conservative]], [[Centrism|centrist]] and [[Nationalism|nationalist]] movements, such as the [[American System (economic plan)|American system]], the [[Meiji Restoration#Centralization|Meiji Restoration]], [[social corporatism]], [[Juche]], and [[traditionalist conservatism]]. [[Fascism|Fascist]] and [[Far-right politics|far-right]] movements occasionally [[Strasserism|claimed]] to strive for autarky in platform or propaganda, but in practice crushed existing movements towards self-sufficiency<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/42462895|title=Italian fascism : its origins & development|orig-year=1938|author=De Grand, Alexander J.|year=2000|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|isbn=0803266227|edition= 3rd|location=Lincoln|oclc=42462895}}</ref> and maintained extensive capital connections in efforts to ready for expansionist war and genocide<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/45896166|title=IBM and the Holocaust : the strategic alliance between Nazi Germany and America's most powerful corporation|last=Edwin.|first=Black,|date=2001|publisher=Crown Publishers|isbn=0609607995|edition= 1st|location=New York|oclc=45896166}}</ref> while allying with traditional business elites.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/58452991|title=The anatomy of fascism|last=O.|first=Paxton, Robert|date=2005|publisher=Vintage Books|isbn=1400033918|edition= 1st Vintage books|location=New York|oclc=58452991}}</ref>
Autarky may be a policy of a state or other entity when it seeks to be self-sufficient as a whole, but also can be limited to a narrow field such as possession of a key raw material. For example, many countries have a policy of autarky with respect to foodstuffs<ref>{{cite web |url=http://aic.ucdavis.edu/research1/BerlinSumner.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20140120232431/http://aic.ucdavis.edu/research1/BerlinSumner.pdf |archivedate=2014-01-20 |df= }}</ref> and water for national security reasons. By contrast, autarky may be a result of economic isolation or external circumstances in which a state or other entity reverts to localized production when it lacks currency or excess production to trade with the outside world.<ref>{{cite journal | title=Computer Simulations of International Trade and Conflict | journal=Economic Interdependence and International Conflict: New Perspectives on an Enduring Debate | editor1=Mansfield, Edward D.|editor2=Pollins, Brian M. | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L53fR-TusZAC | page=333| isbn=0472022938 | date=2009-09-15 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title=Socialism in Provence, 1871–1914 | author=Judt, Tony | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DeygBwAAQBAJ | page=263| isbn=9780814743553 | date=2011-05-01 }}</ref>
== Etymology ==
The word ''autarky'' is from the {{lang-el|αὐτάρκεια}}, which means "self-sufficiency" (derived from αὐτο-, "self," and ἀρκέω, "to suffice"). The term is sometimes confused with [[autocracy]] (Greek: αὐτoκρατία "government by single absolute ruler") or [[autarchy]] (Greek: αὐταρχία – the idea of rejecting government and ruling oneself and no other).
== History ==
===Ancient and medieval=== Early state societies that can be regarded as autarkic include [[nomadic pastoralism]] and [[palace economy]], though over time these tend towards becoming less self-sufficient and more interconnected. The late [[Bronze Age]], for example, saw formerly self-sufficient palace economies rely more heavily on trade, which may have been a contributing factor to the eventual [[Late Bronze Age collapse|Bronze Age Collapse]] when multiple crises hit those systems at once.
[[Medieval commune]]s combined an attempt at overall economic self-sufficiency through the use of common lands and resources with mutual defense pacts against the depredations of the local nobility. Many of these communes later became trading powers such as the [[Hanseatic League]]. In some cases, communal village economies maintained their own debt system<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/426794447|title=Debt : the first 5,000 years|last=David.|first=Graeber,|year=2011|publisher=Melville House|isbn=1612191290|location=Brooklyn, N.Y.|oclc=426794447}}</ref> as part of a self-sufficient economy and to avoid reliance on possibly hostile aristocratic or business interests.
===19th and early 20th centuries=== Autarkic ambitions<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/3650099|title=The Populist moment : a short history of the agrarian revolt in America|last=Lawrence.|first=Goodwyn|isbn=0195024176|location=New York|oclc=3650099}}</ref> can also be seen in the [[People's Party (United States)|Populist]] backlash to the exploitations of free trade in the late 19th-century and in many early [[Utopian socialism|Utopian Socialist]] movements. [[Benefit society|Mutual aid societies]] like the [[National Grange of the Order of Patrons of Husbandry|Grange]] and [[Sovereigns of Industry]] attempted to set up self-sufficient economies (with varying degrees of success) in an effort to be less dependent on what they saw as an exploitative economic system and to generate more power to push for reforms.
Early socialist movements used these autarkic efforts to build their base with institutions like the [[Bourse du Travail|Bourse de travail]], socialist canteens and food assistance. These played a major role in securing workers' loyalty and building those parties into increasingly powerful institutions (especially in Europe) throughout the late 19th and early 20th-centuries. Through these cooperatives<ref>{{Cite book |url= https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/731911132 |title= The Guns of August: The proud tower |last= Tuchman |first= Barbara W. |year=2012 |publisher= Library of America |others= MacMillan, Margaret |isbn= 159853145X |location= New York, NY |pages=1046 |oclc= 731911132}}</ref> "workers bought Socialist bread and Socialist shoes, drank Socialist beer, arranged for Socialist vacations and obtained a Socialist education."
Local and regional farming autarkies in many areas of [[Africa]] and [[Southeast Asia]] were displaced<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/37392803|title=Seeing like a state : how certain schemes to improve the human condition have failed|last=C.|first=Scott, James|date=1998|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=0300070160|location=New Haven|oclc=37392803}}</ref> by European colonial administrations in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, who sought to push smallholder villages into larger plantations that, while less productive, they could more easily control.
Communist movements embraced or dismissed autarky as a goal at different times. Some socialist communities like [[Charles Fourier]]'s [[Phalanstère|phalansteres]] strove for self-sufficiency. The early [[Soviet Union|USSR]] in the [[Russian Civil War]] strove for a self-sufficient economy<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/40510540|title=Red victory : a history of the Russian Civil War|last=Bruce.|first=Lincoln, W.|year=1999|publisher=Da Capo|isbn=0306809095|edition= 1st Da Capo Press|location=New York|oclc=40510540}}</ref> with [[War communism|War Communism]], but later pursued international trade vigorously under the [[New Economic Policy]]. However, while the Soviet government during the latter period encouraged some international trade, it also permitted and even encouraged<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/30841557|title=The making of the Soviet system : essays in the social history of interwar Russia|last=1921-2010.|first=Lewin, Moshe,|date=1994|publisher=New Press|isbn=1565841255|location=New York|oclc=30841557}}</ref> local autarkies in many peasant villages.
Right-wing totalitarian governments that have claimed to strive for autarky have often pursued a very different policy in fact, just as some claimed to be in favor of socialism while killing socialists. In 1921 Italian [[Italian Fascism|Fascists]] attacked existing left-wing autarkic projects at the behest of large landowners, destroying roughly 119 labor chambers, 107 cooperatives and 83 peasant offices that year alone.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/42462895|title=Italian fascism : its origins & development|last=De Grand|first= Alexander J.|year=2000|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|isbn=0803266227|edition= 3rd|location=Lincoln|pages=31–33|oclc=42462895}}</ref> [[Nazi Germany]] under economics minister [[Hjalmar Schacht]] claimed to strive for self-sufficiency but pursued major international trade, albeit under a different system, to escape the terms of the [[Treaty of Versailles]]. The regime would continue to conduct trade, including with countries like the United States, including connections with major companies like [[IBM and the Holocaust|IBM]] and [[Fanta|Coca-Cola]].
===After World War II=== Economic self-sufficiency was pursued as a goal by some members of the [[Non-Aligned Movement]], such as [[India]] under [[Jawaharlal Nehru]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=NAYAR|first=BALDEV RAJ|date=1997|title=Nationalist Planning for Autarky and State Hegemony : Development Strategy Under Nehru|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/24010467|journal=Indian Economic Review|volume=32|issue=1|pages=13–38}}</ref> and [[Tanzania]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Malima|first=Kighoma A.|date=1979|title=PLANNING FOR SELF-RELIANCE TANZANIA'S THIRD FIVE YEAR DEVELOPMENT PLAN|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/24498250|journal=Africa Development / Afrique et Développement|volume=4|issue=1|pages=37–56}}</ref> under the ideology of [[Ujamaa]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1024254210|title=State Ideology and Language in Tanzania : Second and Revised Edition.|last=Jan.|first=Blommaert,|date=2014|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780748668267|edition= 2nd|location=Oxford|oclc=1024254210}}</ref> and swadeshi. hat was partly an effort to escape the economic domination of both the United States and the Soviet Union while modernizing the countries' infrastructure.
Small-scale autarkies were sometimes used by the [[Civil rights movement|Civil Rights Movement]], such as in the case of the [[Montgomery bus boycott|Montgomery Bus Boycott]], where boycotters set up their own self-sufficient system of cheap or free transit to allow black residents to get to work and avoid using the then-segregated public systems in a successful effort to bring political pressure.
After World War II, [[Autonomism|Autonomist efforts]] in Europe embraced autarkic projects in an effort to craft anti-authoritarian left-wing spaces, especially influencing the [[social center]] and [[squatting|squatters]]' rights movements. Such efforts remain a common feature of Autonomist and anarchist movements on the continent today. The Micropolis social centre in Greece, for example, has gyms, restaurants, bars, meeting space and free distribution of food and resources.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/984595655|title=Antifa : the anti-fascist handbook|last=activist),|first=Bray, Mark (Political|isbn=1612197035|location=Brooklyn, NY|oclc=984595655}}</ref>
Around 1970, the [[Black Panther Party]] moved away from communist internationalism towards "intercommunalism," a term coined<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://libcom.org/library/huey-newton-introduces-revolutionary-intercommunalism-boston-college-november-18-1970|title=Huey Newton introduces Revolutionary Intercommunalism, Boston College, November 18 1970|website=libcom.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-12}}</ref> by [[Huey P. Newton]], "to retain a grasp on the local when the rest of radical thought seemed to be moving global." Intercommunalism drew<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thenewinquiry.com/the-havoc-of-less/|title=The Havoc of Less|date=2017-09-15|work=The New Inquiry|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-US|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180206132434/https://thenewinquiry.com/the-havoc-of-less/|archivedate=2018-02-06|df=}}</ref> from left-wing autarkic projects like free medical clinics and breakfast programs, "explicitly articulated as attempts to fill a void left by the failure of the federal government to provide resources as basic as food to black communities."
Autarkic efforts to counter forcible privatization of public resources and maintain local self-sufficiency also formed a key part of [[alter-globalization]] efforts. The [[Cochabamba Water War]] had Bolivians successfully oppose the privatization of their water system to keep the resource in public hands.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/56194844|title=Cochabamba!: Water War in Bolivia|last=Oscar.|first=Olivera,|date=2004|publisher=South End Press|others=Lewis, Tom, |isbn=9780896087026|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|oclc=56194844}}</ref>
===Contemporary=== Today, national economic autarkies are relatively rare. A commonly-cited example is [[North Korea]], based on the government ideology of [[Juche]] ([[self-sufficiency]]), which is concerned with maintaining its domestic localized economy in the face of its isolation. However, even North Korea has extensive trade with [[Russia]], [[China]], [[Syria]], [[Iran]], [[Vietnam]], and many countries in Europe and Africa. North Korea had to import food during a widespread [[North Korean famine|famine in the 1990s]].
A better modern example at a societal level is the autonomous region of [[Rojava]], the autonomous northern region of [[Syria]]. Cut off from international trade, facing multiple enemies, and striving for a society based on democratic confederalism and the ideals of [[Murray Bookchin]], Rojava's government and constitution emphasize economic self-sufficiency<ref>{{Cite book|title=A small key can open a large door: the Rojava revolution|editor=Strangers In A Tangled Wilderness|isbn=193866017X|location=United States|oclc=900796070}}</ref> directed by neighborhood and village councils, with property and business belonging to those who live in or use it towards that goal.
An example of an contemporary effort at localized autarky, incorporating the concept's history from [[black nationalism]], Ujamaa and [[African-American socialism]] and the civil rights movement, is Cooperation Jackson,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cooperationjackson.org/|title=Welcome|website=Cooperation Jackson|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-15}}</ref> a movement aimed at creating a self-sufficient black working class economy in [[Jackson, Mississippi]]. The movement has aimed<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/976416348|title=Jackson rising : the struggle for economic recovery and black self-determination in Jackson, Mississippi|others=Nangwaya, Ajamu,, Cooperation Jackson,|isbn=9780995347458|location=Montreal, Quebec|oclc=976416348}}</ref> to secure land and build self-sufficient cooperatives and workplaces "to democratically transform the political economy of the city" and push back against gentrification. Cooperation Jackson also saw a gain in electoral political power when its involvement proved pivotal to the 2013 mayoral election of [[Chokwe Lumumba]] and the 2017 election of his son, [[Chokwe Antar Lumumba]].
==Support and opposition== ===Local autarky=== {{Div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Anarcho-Primitivism]] * [[Commune]] * [[Civil rights movement]] * [[List of food self-sufficiency rates by country]] * [[Green Anarchism]] * [[Kibbutz Movement]] * Libertarian Municipalism * [[Mutualism (movement)|Mutualist movement]] * [[Survivalism]] * [[Traditionalist conservatism]] * [[Transition town]] * [[Urban homesteading]] and [[Integral Urban House]] * [[Utopian socialism]] {{div col end}}
===Societal autarky=== ====Support==== {{Div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Anarchist communism]] * [[Anarcho-syndicalism]] * [[Autonomism]] * [[Business nationalism]] * [[Collectivist anarchism]] * [[Council communism]] * [[De Leonism]] * [[Democratic Confederalism]] * [[Juche]] * [[Khmer rouge]] * [[Mutualism (economic theory)]] * [[Neo-corporatism]] * [[Paleoconservatism]] * [[Populism]] * [[Producerism]] * [[Social corporatism]] * [[Solidarity economy]] * [[Solidarity unionism]] * [[State capitalism]] * [[Syndicalism]] • [[Ujamaa]]{{div col end}}
====Opposition==== {{Div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Anarcho-capitalism]] * [[Classical liberalism]] * [[Commercial Revolution]] * [[Fourth International]] * [[Liberal internationalism]] * [[Libertarian conservatism]] * [[Libertarianism]] * [[Neoconservatism]] * [[Neoliberalism]] * [[Permanent revolution]] * [[Proletarian internationalism]] * [[Stateless communism]] * [[Trotskyism]] * [[World communism]] * [[World revolution]] {{div col end}}
===Macroeconomic theory=== ====Support==== {{Div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Alexander Hamilton]] * [[Alter-globalization]] * [[Anti-globalization movement]] * [[Murray Bookchin]] * [[Celso Furtado]] * [[Core-periphery|Core-periphery model]] * [[Friedrich List]] * [[Global justice movement]] * [[Hans Singer]] * [[Import Substitution Industrialization]] * [[Infant industry argument]] * [[Mercantilism]] * [[Nationalization]] * [[Protectionism]] * [[Raúl Prebisch]] * [[Singer-Prebisch thesis]] * [[Structuralist economics]] {{div col end}}
====Opposition==== {{Div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Andre Gorz]]<ref>Gorz, Andre. "Towards a Dual Society." ''Adieux au proletariat'', translated by Mike Sonenscher, Pluto Press London, 1982. pp. 102-103.</ref> * [[Austrian School of Economics]] * [[Economic liberalism]] * [[Free trade agreement]] * [[Free trade]] * [[Globalization]] * [[Milton Friedman]] * [[Neoclassical economics]] * [[Privatization]] {{div col end}}
