Susan Cheong-Leen
Franklin Cheong-Leen
[[Flora Cheong-Leen]] |signature = Hilton Cheong-Leen signature.svg |footnotes = }} '''Hilton Cheong-Leen''', [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]], [[Justice of Peace|JP]] ({{zh-t|張有興}}; born 6 August 1922) is a Hong Kong politician and businessman. He was an elected member of the [[Urban Council of Hong Kong]] for 34 years from 1957 to 1991. He was also the first Chinese chairman of the council from 1981 to 1986. He had been a long-time chairman of the [[Hong Kong Civic Association]], one of the two quasi-opposition political groups in the post-war Urban Council. From 1973 to 1979, he was appointed [[unofficial member]] of the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong]]. From 1985 to 1988, he was again became among the first elected member of the Legislative Council through [[Urban Council (constituency)|Urban Council constituency]] in the [[Hong Kong legislative election, 1985|first Legislative Council election]] in 1985. ==Early life and business career== Cheong-Leen was born in [[Georgetown, British Guyana|Georgetown]], British Guyana on 6 August 1922 to a third-generation Chinese mother Elvira Cheong-Leen and father Edward Cheong-Leen who came through Hong Kong from China to join an uncle in Guyana. He was educated at the Central High School in Georgetown. He moved to Hong Kong when he was around nine and went to [[La Salle College]] in Hong Kong.{{cite book|page=51|title=Colonialism and the Hong Kong Mentality, Issue 150|first=David|last=Faure|publisher=Centre of Asian Studies, University of Hong Kong|year=2003}} He had worked in a law firm, an import and export company and as a banker after school.{{cite news|title=公民協會宣布推出五人競選|newspaper=Wah Kiu Yat Po|page=5|date=26 January 1956}} After the [[fall of Hong Kong]], he moved to unoccupied territory in China and lived in [[Kunming]] with his family and returned to Hong Kong after the war. He was a journalist for a period of time, having been the Hong Kong correspondent of [[Fox News]] and [[BBC]].{{cite news|title=市政局議員競選人訪問之二張有興談憲政改革|newspaper=Wah Kiu Yat Po|page=6|date=21 February 1956}} He was offered a job with the ''[[South China Morning Post]]'' but he followed his family's wish to go into commerce and set up his own import and export firm H. Cheong-Leen & Co. in 1945, importing gifts, premiums and watches.{{cite book|page=143|title=Asia Who's Who|year=1958}} As a publisher, he also joined the Junior Chamber in 1953 and represented the chamber in the international conference of the Junior Chamber in San Francisco. He was for many years chairman of the Hong Kong Watch Importers Association. He continues to be the honorary life president of the Hong Kong Watch Manufacturers Association.{{cite web|title=H Cheong-Leen & Co (HK) Ltd|work=Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce|url=http://www.chamber.org.hk/hcheongleen/}} ==Early political career== At the time the [[Urban Council]] elections, the only direct elections in the colony at the time, were dominated by [[Brook Bernacchi]]'s [[Reform Club of Hong Kong]], Cheong-Leen founded the [[Hong Kong Civic Association]] in 1954 with [[Roger Lobo]] and [[A. de O. Sales]], as well as Rev. [[Brigant Cassian]] and Dr. [[Woo Pak-foo]]. Cheong-Leen was the founding secretary-general of the association and was in the first meeting at a bar on the mezzanine floor of Jimmy's Kitchen in [[Theatre Lane]], [[Central, Hong Kong|Central]].{{cite news|title=Hilton Cheong-leen|date=28 July 2003|first=Hilton|last=Cheong-leen|newspaper=South China Morning Post|url=http://www.scmp.com/article/423095/hilton-cheong-leen}} As the representative of the association, he visited London and New York and met with the [[Colonial Office]] officials and [[Members of Parliament (UK)|Members of Parliament]] of different parties including [[John Peel (Leicester MP)|William John Peel]], son of Hong Kong Governor Sir [[William Peel (colonial administrator)|William Peel]], and United Nations officials [[Ralph Bunche]] and [[Benjamin Victor Cohen]] over constitutional reform and other issues respectively in the 1950s. He was also vice-chairman of the [[United Nations Association of Hong Kong]] led by [[Ma Man-fai]], whom he befriended during their lives in Kunming. He represented the association in the international conference of the United Nations Association in Bangkok in 1955. As a secretary of the International Association of the Chinese Refugees, he also visited [[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees]] in Geneva and New York on the refuge issues in Hong Kong. ==Urban Councillor== Cheong-Leen first contested on the Civic Association ticket in [[Hong Kong municipal election, 1956|1956 Urban Council election]] but was not elected. He ran again in the [[Hong Kong municipal election, 1957|election]] in the following year and took the last of the four seats. He remained in the Urban Council for 34 years until he retired in 1991. He took over as the Civic Association chairman in 1968 and had held the position for many years until 2004. The Civic Association at the time positioned itself as more pro-middle-class and moderate as compared to the Reform Club. Cheong-Leen contested the chairmanship of the Urban Council in 1973 when the post was elected by the council for the first time. He lost to [[Arnaldo de Oliveira Sales|A. de O. Sales]] but was elected vice-chairman. He went on becoming the first Chinese chairman of the council in 1981 after defeating [[Denny Huang]] when A. de. O. Sales stepped down. He held the position until 1986. He had also many other public positions including the chairman of the Hong Kong Girl Guides Island Regional Association, deputy chairman of the council of the [[Hong Kong Academy for Performing Arts]], member of the Fight Crime Committee, board of governors of the [[Hong Kong Philharmonic Orchestra|Hong Kong Philharmonic Society]] and the Hong Kong Academy of Ballet. He was also member of the [[Wan Chai District Board]] as an ex officio member. For his public services, he was awarded [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in 1984.{{London Gazette|date=16 June 1984|supp=y |issue=49768|page=16}} After 34 years of service, Cheong-Leen stepped down as the second longest-serving elected officeholder in Hong Kong history, behind [[Brook Bernacchi]]'s 41 years, after he decided not to seek for re-election of the Urban Council in 1991.{{cite news|title=本港有史以來任期最長民選議員張有興放棄參選市局話別卅四載議員生涯|newspaper=Wah Kiu Yat Po|page=5|date=20 March 1991}} ==Legislative Councillor== He was first appointed as an [[unofficial member]] of the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong]] on 1 May 1973 by [[Governor of Hong Kong|Governor]] Sir [[Murray MacLehose]] with [[Guy Sayer]] to fill the vacancies left by retired [[Herbert John Charles Browne|H. J. C. Browne]] and deceased [[Mary Wong Wing-cheung]].{{cite news|title=張有興沙雅二人出任立法局議員|newspaper=Wah Kiu Yat Po|page=13|date=26 April 1973}} In his first term in the council, he made a major speech advocating nine years of free compulsory education and followed up all the way to the [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]], which made it eventually realised. He retired from the Legislative Council on 31 August 1979 along with [[James Wu Man-hon]] after six years of service and were succeeded by [[Hu Fa-kuang]] and [[Wong Po-yan]]. In the 1980s, the colonial government carried out the constitutional reform as the [[Sino-British Joint Declaration]] was finalised. The [[Hong Kong legislative election, 1985|first indirect election]] was introduced in 1985 when 24 seats of the Legislative Council were elected by electoral colleges and [[functional constituency (Hong Kong)|functional constituencies]]. Cheong-Leen defeated [[Elsie Tu]] in the [[Urban Council (constituency)|Urban Council electoral college]] which composed of all members of the Urban Council and became member of the Legislative Council for the second time. He held the position until 1988. ==Family== Hilton Cheong-Leen's first wife, Pauline Chow, was a soprano singer known as "the nightingale of China". Pauline was born in [[Peking]] and was educated at the Bridgman Academy and [[Peking University|National Peking University]]. The couple met in [[Guilin]] and Hilton was even fancied becoming a base baritone because of her. They married in 1945 until her death in 1979. The couple had two sons and two daughters, Reginald (born in 1951), Susan (born in 1953), Franklin (born in 1958) and Flora (born in 1959). Their fourth child, [[Flora Cheong-Leen]] is a famous ballerina and designer who was married to actor [[Russell Wong]]. He married his second wife, Nancy Gan Wan Geok, in 1988 but later divorced. Gan was a classical pianist and porcelain painter educated at [[Trinity College London]] and had held exhibitions of her porcelain paintings in Hong Kong from 1988 to 1992. Gan was found dead in the swimming pool of her bungalow in Singapore on 19 March 2014. Dewi Suko Wati, her Indonesian helper from Central Java, was charged with murder.{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1453426/indonesian-helper-charged-killing-hong-kong-born-socialite-singapore|title=Indonesian helper charged with killing Hong Kong-born socialite in Singapore|date=21 March 2014|first=Ada|last=Lee|newspaper=South China Morning Post}}{{cite news|last=Jo|first=Yeo Sam|title=Socialite's body found in swimming pool; maid held|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/socialites-body-found-in-swimming-pool-maid-held|newspaper=The Straits Times|date=20 March 2014|accessdate=31 December 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Woo Pak-chuen]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Member of the [[Urban Council]]|years=1957–1991}} {{s-aft|after=[[San Stephen Wong Hon-ching|San Stephen Wong]]}} {{s-bef|before=[[Arnaldo de Oliveira Sales]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Chairman of the Urban Council|years=1981–1986}} {{s-aft|after=[[Hugh Moss Gerald Forsgate]]}} {{s-ppo|hk}} {{s-bef|before=[[Woo Pak-foo]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Chairman of the [[Hong Kong Civic Association]]|years=1968–2004}} {{s-aft|after=[[Lam Kwok-wah]]}} {{s-par|hk}} {{s-bef|before=[[Herbert John Charles Browne]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Unofficial Member]]|years=1973–1979}} {{s-aft|after=[[Wong Po-yan]]}} {{s-new|constituency}} {{s-ttl|title=Member of [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong]]|district=[[Urban Council (constituency)|Urban Council]]|years=1985–1988}} {{s-aft|after=[[Elsie Tu]]}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cheong-Leen, Hilton}} [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the Legislative Council of Hong Kong]] [[Category:Members of the Urban Council of Hong Kong]] [[Category:Hong Kong Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Hong Kong businesspeople]] [[Category:Hong Kong journalists]] [[Category:Hong Kong Civic Association politicians]] [[Category:Hong Kong people of Guyanese descent]] [[Category:United Nations Association of Hong Kong politicians]] [[Category:Guyanese people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:People from Georgetown, Guyana]] [[Category:District councillors of Wan Chai District]] [[Category:HK LegCo Members 1985–88]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of the British Empire]]

[[J. Schuyler Long]] (great-great-grandfather) | awards = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Howard Warren Buffett''' (born October 14, 1983) is an American professor in public policy and international affairs, political advisor, and philanthropist. He serves as an adjunct faculty member at Columbia University's [[School of International and Public Affairs, Columbia University|School of International and Public Affairs]]{{cite web|url=http://new.sipa.columbia.edu/faculty/howard-buffett|title=Howard W. Buffett - Columbia SIPA|website=new.sipa.columbia.edu|accessdate=May 29, 2018}} and was previously the executive director of the Howard G. Buffett Foundation, a private philanthropic foundation that funds initiatives aimed at improving the standard of living and quality of life for the world’s most impoverished and marginalized populations.[http://mashable.com/sgs/speakers/#hbuffett "Mashable & 92Y Social Good Summit - Speakers"] [[Mashable]] Retrieved October 17, 2011. He previously led agriculture-based economic stabilization and redevelopment programs in Iraq and Afghanistan while at the [[United States Department of Defense]],[http://mashable.com/un-week/social-good-summit/agenda/ "Mashable & 92Y Social Good Summit - Agenda."] [[Mashable]] Retrieved September 26, 2010. and as a policy advisor in the [[Executive Office of the President of the United States]] under President [[Barack Obama]]. Prior to joining the [[White House]], Buffett served as a special assistant at the [[U.S. Department of Agriculture]],[http://www.philanthropy.iupui.edu/buildingtrust/speakers/buffett.aspx "Building Trust Annual Symposium"] [[Indiana University – Purdue University Indianapolis]]. Retrieved July 16, 2010. as a member of the [[Office of the President-Elect]],Kang, Cecilia (November 25, 2008) [http://voices.washingtonpost.com/posttech/2008/11/obama_names_team_to_create_inn.html "Obama Names Team To Create "Innovation Agenda""]. [[The Washington Post]]. Retrieved July 16, 2010. and as director of National Surrogate Radio for [[Barack Obama presidential campaign, 2008|Obama for America]].[http://change.gov/learn/policy_working_groups "Policy Working Groups"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090105162044/http://change.gov/learn/policy_working_groups |date=January 5, 2009 }} [[Office of the President-Elect]]. Retrieved July 16, 2010. ==Early life and education== Buffett was born in [[Omaha, Nebraska]], to farmer and philanthropist [[Howard Graham Buffett]] and Devon Armour Goss (by first husband Morse).{{cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/65038624/|title=Pasadena Independent from Pasadena, California on August 16, 1966 · Page 4|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.therichest.com/celebnetworth/celebrity-business/men/howard-buffett-net-worth/|title=Howard Buffett Net Worth - TheRichest|website=www.therichest.com}}{{cite web|url=https://relationshipscience.com/devon-goss-buffett-p44080476|title=Devon Goss Buffett, Executive Vice President, Secretary, Director at Howard G. Buffett Foundation - Relationship Science|website=relationshipscience.com}} He has four half sisters: Erin Christian Morse, Heather Kirsten Morse, Chelsea Armour Morse, Megan Moreton Morse. He is a grandson and a only biological grandchild of famed American investor and philanthropist [[Warren Edward Buffett]].Chang, Yi-Hsin (May 5, 1999) [http://www.fool.com/specials/1999/sp990502omaha004.htm "Woodstock for Capitalists"]. [[The Motley Fool]]. Retrieved July 16, 2010. His maternal grandfather was Norman Leffingwell Goss, a celebrity Pasadena businessman, a restaurateur, a vineyard and winery owner and a classical musician. And he is a great-great-grandson of Michael Cochrane Armour, president of a Chicago Iron and Steel Corporation.{{cite web|url=https://lahabraericsons.wordpress.com/chester-franklin-ericson/|title=Chester Franklin Ericson & The Armours|date=February 15, 2015|publisher=}} Howard Warren Buffett is also a great-great-grandson of Dr. [[J. Schuyler Long]]. Raised in Omaha, he attended Ponca Elementary School before moving to [[Decatur, Illinois]], where he attended [[Mount Zion, Illinois#Mount Zion High School|Mount Zion High School]] and was elected president of the local chapter of the [[National FFA Organization]]. He completed his [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[Political Science]] and [[Communication Studies]] in 2006 at [[Northwestern University]] in [[Evanston, Illinois]],Thompson, Peter (November 22, 2002) [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-70215042.html "Life NewVoices Military"] KRT Direct. Retrieved July 16, 2010. where he also served as the student body vice president.Angela Tablac, Erin Stock (April 16, 2004) [http://www.dailynorthwestern.com/2.13939/fierce-competition-in-all-races-frames-asg-elections-1.1987834 "Fierce Competition in All Races Frames ASG Elections"]. [[The Daily Northwestern]]. Retrieved July 16, 2010. He went on to receive a [[Master of Public Administration]] in Advanced Management and Finance at the [[School of International and Public Affairs, Columbia University]] in 2008.[http://www.whitehouse.gov/administration/eop/sicp/staff/buffett "Executive Office of the President Staff"] [[The White House]]. Retrieved July 16, 2010. ==Career== ===Public service=== In 2009, Buffett was appointed to the [[United States Department of Agriculture]], where he served as a special assistant in the Office of the Secretary. There, he managed the national expansion strategy for the Department’s $480 million [[Cooperative Extension Service]] program. Additionally, he was charged with identifying strategic external partnerships aimed at advancing the core mission areas of research, education, and economics. He also served on the five-year Strategic Planning Initiative, and represented the department in the White House Innovation and Information Policy Working Group.Buffett, Howard (May 10, 2010) [http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2010/05/10/promoting-partnerships-innovation-energy "Promoting Partnerships for Innovation in Energy"]. [[The White House]]. Retrieved July 16, 2010. Upon completion of his service at the Department of Agriculture, Buffett served as a policy advisor in the Executive Office of the President of the United States at the White House, where he was responsible for the Cross-Sector Partnerships portfolio. In this role, he directed strategy development for cross-sector partnerships and innovation strategies aimed at enhancing collaboration between the White House, federal departments, agencies, corporations, nonprofits and foundations. After leaving the White House, Buffett became the director of agriculture development at the Task Force for Business Stability Operations under the [[U.S. Department of Defense]], where he was tasked with designing and implementing a strategy for agricultural development in Afghanistan and Iraq under the leadership of [[Paul Brinkley]].[http://mashable.com/un-week/social-good-summit/speakers/ "Mashable & 92Y Social Good Summit - Speakers"] [[Mashable]]. Retrieved September 26, 2010. ===White House Energy Innovation Conference=== In May 2010, Buffett spearheaded a [[White House Energy Innovation Conference]] focused on promoting partnerships. Represented at the event were four federal departments, three federal agencies, entrepreneurs, state government officials, academia, private sector leaders, nonprofits and innovators. At the conference, the [[United States Department of Energy]] and the [[Small Business Administration]] jointly announced that both the Small Business Investment Company program and the Small Business Technology Transfer program would begin using their existing funding networks to promote small green energy firms through a new $60 million Business Clean Energy Innovation Fund. The event also served as the launch vehicle for the Regional Energy Innovation Conferences. The first Regional Energy Innovation Conference was hosted in [[Omaha, Nebraska]] on June 17, 2010. The event focused on connecting entrepreneurs and small enterprise with representatives from organizations across sectors and was itself a partnership between the City of Omaha, [[The Gallup Organization]], the [[Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation]], and the [[U.S. Department of Energy]]. Over one hundred local, regional, and national organizations were represented at Gallup University’s Omaha Campus to discuss issues ranging from regional gap funding and human capital needs to collaboration and the early adoption of energy innovation.Buffett, Howard (June 17, 2010)[http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2010/06/17/partnerships-regional-energy-innovation-omaha-nebraska "Partnerships for Regional Energy Innovation in Omaha, Nebraska"] [[The White House]]. Retrieved July 16, 2010. ===Social value investing=== At the 2011 Social Good Summit in New York, Buffett introduced an approach premised on addressing social problems by systematically lining up nonprofits to each need.Ferenstein, Gregory (September 6, 2011) [http://www.fastcompany.com/1772527/howard-buffett-foundation-whos-next-nonprofit-charity "How Howard Buffett Will Use His Grandfather's Recipe For Riches To Disrupt Philanthropy"] ''[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]''. Retrieved October 17, 2011. On May 28, 2018, Buffett announced the release of his book titled "Social Value Investing: A Management Framework for Effective Partnerships."{{cite web|last1=Bloomberg News|title=How Social Value Investing Can Solve Some Of The World's Challenges|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2018-05-29/how-social-value-investing-can-solve-some-of-the-world-s-challenges-video|website=Bloomberg News|accessdate=May 29, 2018}} Published by [[Columbia University Press]], the book details specific case studies and examples on topics including clean energy, water scarcity and sustainable agriculture.{{cite web|last1=School of International and Public Affairs|first1=Columbia University|title=Social Value Investing Case Study Collection|url=https://sipa.columbia.edu/svi-case-collection|website=Columbia University|accessdate=May 29, 2018}} ===Advisory positions=== In 2010, Buffett joined the advisory board for [[Toyota Motor North America]].[http://corporatenews.pressroom.toyota.com/releases/toyota+diversity+advisory+board+nov10.htm "Toyota Names Jyoti Chopra and Howard W. Buffett to Its North American Diversity Advisory Board"]. Toyota Motor North America. Retrieved May 29, 2018. He chairs the advisory board for the [[Harvard University]] International Negotiation Program.{{when|date=May 2018}}[https://inp.harvard.edu/people/howard-w-buffett "Harvard International Negotiation Program, Who we Are"]. Harvard University. Retrieved May 29, 2018. He previously served on the Board of Visitors for the Center on Philanthropy at [[Indiana University]],{{when|date=December 2016}} and on the boards of New York Needs You and the Clark and Hinman Foundation.{{when|date=December 2016}} Additionally, he has served as an advisor to both the [[United Nations Office for Partnerships]] and the FEED Foundation.{{when|date=December 2016}}[https://www.un.org/partnerships/YStaffHowardWBuffett.htm "United Nations Office for Partnerships Staff"] the [[United Nations Office for Partnerships]]. Retrieved July 16, 2010. He served as a judge for the Collaboration Prize,{{when|date=December 2016}}[http://www.thecollaborationprize.org/Media/News/Lodestar-Foundation-Announces-Final-Selection-Pane.aspx "Lodestar Foundation Announces Final Selection Pane"] The Collaboration Prize. Retrieved July 16, 2010. the [[American Express]] 2009 NGen Fellows Program, and the [[Network for Teaching Entrepreneurship]]’s business plan competitions. He is an active member of the Nebraska Society and a lifetime alumni member of the [[Future Farmers of America]] (FFA).[http://www.nebraskasociety.org/membership.html "Members of the Nebraska Society of Washington D.C."]. The Nebraska Society of Washington D.C. Retrieved July 16, 2010. ===Philanthropy=== Buffett currently{{when|date=December 2016}} serves as the executive director of the Howard G. Buffett Foundation, a private family foundation focused on improving the standard of living and quality of life for the world’s most impoverished and marginalized populations. He has engaged in the humanitarian and agriculture development efforts of the Foundation worldwide.Walton, Don (June 12, 2010) [http://journalstar.com/news/local/article_f2d78422-75a1-11df-835a-001cc4c03286.html "A Young Buffett Eyes Public Service in Nebraska"] [[The Lincoln Journal Star]]. Retrieved July 16, 2010. Buffett also sits on the board of [[Doris Buffett]]'s Learning By Giving Foundation. He has referred to Learning by Giving as the first step in the implementation of the Social Value Investment model, "By simply empowering students to become problem solvers in their own communities, we maximize the impact of our efforts, encourage innovation, and inspire life-long engagements with philanthropy."Learning by Giving Foundation [http://www.learningbygivingfoundation.org/front-page "Learning by Giving Foundation - Howard W. Buffett Speech to the 2011 Social Good Summit"]. Retrieved October 17, 2011. ===Professor=== In the fall of 2013, Buffett served as a co-professor teaching an Innovations of Public Management class at his alma mater at the [[School of International and Public Affairs]] at Columbia University. Buffett taught the course with program head William Eimicke, and is currently an adjunct associate professor and research scholar at the school, teaching philanthropy, social value investing, and management innovation.Columbia University School of International and Public Affairs [https://sipa.columbia.edu/faculty-research/faculty-directory/howard-w-buffett "Faculty Directory: Howard W. Buffett"]. Retrieved May 29, 2018. ==Personal life== He is married to Lili Thomas Buffett. They split their time between Omaha, Nebraska, and Decatur, Illinois.The Reliable Source (September 19, 2011) [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/reliable-source/post/love-etc-howard-buffett-and-lili-thomas-wed/2011/09/19/gIQAqGQ7fK_blog.html "Love, etc.: Howard Buffett and Lili Thomas Wed"] [[The Washington Post]]. Retrieved October 17, 2011. Buffett operates a 400-acre [[no-till farming|no-till farm]] near [[Tekamah, Nebraska]].{{when|date=December 2016}}Steve Jordon (June 10, 2011) [http://www.omaha.com/article/20110610/MONEY/706109891/-1 "Buffett Grandson to Run Dad's Foundation"] [[Omaha World Herald]]. Retrieved October 17, 2011. Buffett is a published photographer, his work has appeared in ''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]'',{{when|date=December 2016}}{{NatGeo ecoregion|id=at0713_pto|name=Sahelian Acacia Savanna|accessdate=July 16, 2010}} [[World Wide Fund for Nature]],[http://www.worldwildlife.org/who/media/press/2009/WWFPresitem14175.html "Nepal Expands Critical Tiger Habitat"] [[World Wide Fund for Nature]]. Retrieved July 16, 2010. and ''[[Encyclopedia of Earth]]''.[http://www.eoearth.org/article/Sahelian_Acacia_savanna "Sahelian Acacia Savanna"] [[Encyclopedia of the Earth]]. Retrieved July 16, 2010. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.whitehouse.gov/administration/eop/sicp/ The White House Office of Social Innovation and Civic Participation Official Website] * [http://www.whitehouse.gov/ The White House Official Website] {{Buffett Family}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Buffett, Howard W.}} [[Category:1983 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American farmers]] [[Category:Philanthropists from Illinois]] [[Category:Artists from Chicago]] [[Category:Artists from Omaha, Nebraska]] [[Category:Buffett family|Howard Warren Buffett]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Omaha, Nebraska]] [[Category:Columbia University faculty]] [[Category:Nebraska Democrats]] [[Category:Northwestern University alumni]] [[Category:School of International and Public Affairs, Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Obama administration personnel]] [[Category:People from Decatur, Illinois]] [[Category:Photographers from Nebraska]] [[Category:United States Department of Defense officials]] [[Category:United States Department of Agriculture officials]]

The '''Internet Society of China''' (ISC) is a [[China|Chinese]] [[non-governmental organization]] made up of 140 members of the Chinese Internet industry including private companies, schools and research institutes.<ref>{{cite news|last=Associated Press|title=China Sites Pledge to Be Nice|url=https://www.wired.com/politics/law/news/2002/07/53856|accessdate=12 December 2011|newspaper=Wired magazine|date=15 July 2002}}</ref> It is supported by Chinese government authorities such as the [[Ministry of Information Industry]], the [[Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China|Ministry of Education]] and the [[State Council Information Office]]. It describes itself as “the country’s first non-governmental regulator for the internet industry.”
ISC has been described as a "quasi-governmental" organization.<ref name="MacKinnon2012">{{cite book|author=Rebecca MacKinnon|title=Consent of the Networked: The Worldwide Struggle For Internet Freedom|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A1Ll03dPL1cC&pg=PP35|accessdate=15 March 2012|date=31 January 2012|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=978-0-465-02442-1|page=35}}</ref>
== History and regulation == The ISC issues what the Chinese government calls “self-disciplinary regulations,” including the [[Public Pledge on Self-Discipline for the Chinese Internet Industry]], which has been signed by thousands of organizations operating websites in China, including [[Baidu]], [[Soseen]], [[Yahoo]], [[Microsoft]] and [[Google]]. In signing the agreement, companies pledge to identify and prevent the transmission of any information that Chinese authorities deem objectionable, including information that “breaks laws or spreads superstition or obscenity,” or that “may jeopardize state security and disrupt social stability.” <ref>{{cite news|last=Einhorn and Ben Elgin|first=Bruce|title=The Great Firewall Of China|url=http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/06_04/b3968055.htm|accessdate=11 December 2011|newspaper=Business Week magazine|date=23 January 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Kine|first=Phelim|title=China's Internet Crackdown|url=https://www.forbes.com/2010/05/27/china-internet-web-censor-surveillance-technology-security-google-yahoo-green-dam.html|accessdate=11 December 2011|newspaper=Forbes|date=27 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Alfred|first=Hermida|title=Behind China's internet Red Firewall|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/2234154.stm|accessdate=11 December 2011|newspaper=BBC|date=3 September 2002}}</ref>
The ISC is unrelated to the international non-profit [[Internet Society]].
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Business organizations based in China]]
{{org-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = John Jay Mortimer | birth_date = 1935 | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | death_date = 2013 | death_place = [[Tuxedo Park, New York|Tuxedo Park]], New York, U.S. | occupation = | spouse = Senga Clark Mucci Davis | education = [[St. Mark's School (Massachusetts)|St. Mark's School]] | alma_mater = | parents = Stanley Grafton Mortimer, Sr.
Kathleen Hunt Tilford | children = [[Minnie Mortimer]]
Topper Mortimer | relations = [[Katharine Mortimer]] (sister)
[[Richard Mortimer]] (grandfather) }} '''John Jay Mortimer''' (1935 – 2013){{cite web|title=1940 United States Federal Census|url=https://www.ancestry.com/interactive/2442/m-t0627-02655-01013/11137332?backurl=&ssrc=&backlabel=Return|website=www.ancestry.com|accessdate=12 October 2017}} was an American financier and member of the prominent Mortimer family of New York. ==Early life== He was one of six children born to Stanley Grafton Mortimer, Sr. (1890–1947){{cite news|last1=Staff|title=S.G. MORTIMER DIES|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1947/04/06/96582843.html?pageNumber=60|accessdate=12 October 2017|website=The New York Times|date=April 6, 1947}} and Kathleen Hunt Tilford (1890–1970).{{cite news|title=Deaths BLAINE, KATHARINE MORTIMER|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/17/classified/paid-notice-deaths-blaine-katharine-morti-mer.html|accessdate=12 October 2017|website=The New York Times|date=April 17, 2003}} His father was a stockbroker and U.S. amateur court tennis champion. His siblings included Stanley G. Mortimer, Jr. (1913–1999),{{cite news|title=Paid Notice: Deaths MORTIMER, STANLEY G.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/13/classified/paid-notice-deaths-mortimer-stanley-g.html|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=13 August 1999}} who was married to [[Babe Paley]] (1915-1978){{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Barbara Cushing Paley Dies at 63; Style Pace-Setter in Three Decades; Symbol of Taste |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1978/07/07/archives/barbara-cushing-paley-dies-at-63-style-pacesetter-in-three-decades.html |quote=Barbara Cushing Paley, the wife of William S. Paley, the chairman of the board of the Columbia Broadcasting System, died of cancer at their apartment in New York City yesterday after a long illness. She was 63 years old. |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 7, 1978 |accessdate=12 October 2017| first=Enid | last=Nemy}} and then Kathleen H. Harriman (1917-2011),{{cite news|last1=Nemy|first1=Enid|title=Stanley G. Mortimer Jr., 86, Sportsman and Ad Executive|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/14/nyregion/stanley-g-mortimer-jr-86-sportsman-and-ad-executive.html|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=14 August 1999}} the daughter of [[W. Averell Harriman]],{{cite news|last1=Fox|first1=Margalit|title=Kathleen Mortimer, Rich and Adventurous, Dies at 93|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/20/us/20mortimer.html|accessdate=12 October 2017|website=The New York Times|date=February 19, 2011}} Henry Tilford Mortimer (1916-1993),{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Sally Bedell|title=In All His Glory: The Life and Times of William S. Paley and the Birth of Modern Broadcasting|date=2012|publisher=Random House Publishing Group|isbn=9780307786715|page=436|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W4IgALTXtH4C&pg=PT436&lpg=PT436|accessdate=12 October 2017|language=en}}{{cite news|last1=Staff|title=Henry T. Mortimer; Stockbroker, 77|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/09/08/obituaries/henry-t-mortimer-stockbroker-77.html|accessdate=12 October 2017|website=The New York Times|date=September 8, 1993}} Richard Mortimer, Eve Mortimer (1918-2007),{{cite news|title=Eve Mortimer Ledyard of West Grove|url=http://www.dailylocal.com/article/DL/20071004/TMP01/310049987|accessdate=12 October 2017|date=10 October 2007|language=en}} who married Clarence Pell, Jr. and later [[Lewis Cass Ledyard]] III (1911-1990).{{cite news|last1=Wallace|first1=Andrew|title=Lewis C. Ledyard 3d, A Lawyer Who Turned To Art, Horse Breeding|url=http://articles.philly.com/1990-12-05/news/25921847_1_yearlings-farm-lawyer|accessdate=12 October 2017|website=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=December 5, 1990}} His youngest sister, [[Katharine Mortimer]] (1923–2003), was married three times, including to [[Francis Xavier Shields]], who became the grandfather of actress [[Brooke Shields]].{{cite news|title=Deaths BLAINE, KATHARINE MORTIMER|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/17/classified/paid-notice-deaths-blaine-katharine-morti-mer.html|accessdate=15 March 2016|website=The New York Times|date=12 October 2017}} He was a member of the prominent [[Standard Oil]] family, Mortimer is the maternal grandson of its president Henry Morgan Tilford.{{cite news|last1=Morgan|first1=Spencer|title=The Mortimer Family|url=https://observer.com/2006/12/the-mortimer-family/|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[Observer Media|Observer]]|date=18 December 2006}} His paternal grandfather was [[Richard Mortimer]], a real estate investor and member of [[Ward McAllister]]'s [[Ward McAllister#"The Four Hundred"|"Four Hundred"]], purported to be an index of New York's best families.{{cite news|last1=McAllister|first1=Ward|title=THE ONLY FOUR HUNDRED {{!}} WARD M'ALLISTER GIVES OUT THE OFFICIAL LIST. HERE ARE THE NAMES, DON'T YOU KNOW, ON THE AUTHORITY OF THEIR GREAT LEADER, YOU UNDER- STAND, AND THEREFORE GENUINE, YOU SEE.|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1892/02/16/108210917.pdf|accessdate=26 March 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=16 February 1892|language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Patterson|first1=Jerry E.|title=The First Four Hundred: Mrs. Astor's New York in the Gilded Age|date=2000|publisher=[[Random House]]|isbn=9780847822089|page=218|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZLwMAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=2 March 2018|language=en}} Through his father and paternal grandmother, [[Eleanor Jay Chapman Mortimer]], she was a descendant of the first chief justice of the U.S. Supreme Court, [[John Jay]], as well as the first colonial [[List of colonial governors of New York|Governor of New York]], [[Robert Livingston the Elder|Robert Livingston]]{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|first=William|last=L. Hamilton|date=May 27, 2007|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/27/fashion/weddings/27VOWS.html|title=Stephen Gaghan and Minnie Mortimer}} ==Life== Mortimer grew up at Keewaydin in Tuxedo Park.{{cite news|last1=Gaffney|first1=Adrienne|title=Minnie Mortimer's Upper East Side|url=https://gotham-magazine.com/minnie-mortimers-upper-east-side|accessdate=12 October 2017|date=March 6, 2014|language=en}} The family home was designed by [[Stanford White]] and once belonged to [[Pierre Lorillard III]]. His family, along with the [[Lorillard Tobacco Company|Lorillard]]s, were the founding families of Tuxedo Park.{{cite book|last1=Conant|first1=Jennet|title=Tuxedo Park: A Wall Street Tycoon and the Secret Palace of Science That Changed the Course of World War II|date=2013|publisher=[[Simon and Schuster]]|isbn=9781476767291|page=59|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QQTZAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA59&lpg=PA59|accessdate=12 October 2017|language=en}} His grandmother, the widow of Henry Morgan Tilford, was known as "one of the reigning dowagers of Tuxedo Park" for four decades. According to author [[Sally Bedell Smith]], "her annual debutante dinners before the Autumn Ball determined which young women were approved for New York society." He was educated at [[St. Mark's School (Massachusetts)|St. Mark's School]] in [[Southborough, Massachusetts]]. Mortimer was a financier in New York.{{cite news|last1=Konigsberg|first1=Eric|title=Why Is the Blond Smiling?|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/21/fashion/21topper.html|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=21 October 2007}} ==Personal life== Mortimer was married to Senga Clark ([[née]] Mucci) Mortimer, an editor at ''[[House Beautiful]]'' magazine.{{cite news|last1=Gordon|first1=Meryl|title=No More Mr. Nice Guy {{!}} With the death of owner Glenn Bernbaum, the party's suddenly over at Mortimer's. Café society breaks out the black armbands and exorcises a friend's demons.|url=https://nymag.com/nymetro/food/industry/features/3157/index3.html|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[New York Magazine]]|date=October 5, 1998}} Senga, the daughter of Col. [[Henry Mucci]] (1909–1997),{{cite web|title=Peter Davis {{!}} Editor & Socialite|url=https://ponyboymagazine.com/peter-davis-nyc/|website=ponyboymagazine.com|publisher=Ponyboy Magazine|accessdate=12 October 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Thomas Jr.|first1=Robert McG|title=Henry A. Mucci Dies at 88; Rescued Survivors of Bataan|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/24/us/henry-a-mucci-dies-at-88-rescued-survivors-of-bataan.html|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=24 April 1997}} was previously married and had a son, Dwight F. "Peter" Davis IV, from that marriage to Dwight Davis III,{{cite news|title=Senga Mucci Bride Of Dwight Davis 3d|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F02EFDF163BE13ABC4B52DFB366838E679EDE&legacy=true|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=13 May 1965}} a grandson of [[Dwight F. Davis]], the [[United States Secretary of War|U.S. Secretary of War]].{{cite news|last1=Williams|first1=Alex|title=Peter Davis to Introduce a Society Magazine|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/01/fashion/peter-davis-to-introduce-a-society-magazine.html|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=29 February 2012}} Together, they were the parents of: * Robert Livingston "Topper" Mortimer (b. 1975), who married, and later divorced, [[Tinsley Mortimer|Tinsley Randolph Mercer]] (b. 1975).{{cite news|title=WEDDINGS; Tinsley Mercer, Topper Mortimer|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/05/style/weddings-tinsley-mercer-topper-mortimer.html|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=5 May 2002}} * [[Minnie Mortimer|Marian Fountain "Minnie" Mortimer]] (b. 1980), who married [[Stephen Gaghan]], an [[Academy Awards|Oscar]]-winning filmmaker,{{cite journal|last1=Gaffney|first1=Adrienne|title=Minnie Mortimer's Upper East Side|journal=[[Gotham Magazine]]|date=March 6, 2014|url=https://gotham-magazine.com/minnie-mortimers-upper-east-side|accessdate=29 November 2016}} in 2007. Mortimer died in 2013. His funeral was held in Tuxedo Park,{{cite news|last1=Theodoracopulos|first1=Taki|title=Taki: RIP John Jay, my brave friend who refused to take part in vulture capitalism|url=https://www.spectator.co.uk/2013/11/john-jay-mortimer-was-the-epitome-of-a-gent/|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[The Spectator]]|date=9 November 2013}} and speakers included his son and daughter, and [[Lewis H. Lapham|Lewis Lapham]], the editor. == References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/topper-mortimer-john-jay-mortimer-attend-the-minnie-news-photo/817920016#topper-mortimer-john-jay-mortimer-attend-the-minnie-mortimer-spring-picture-id817920016 Photograph of Topper and John Jay Mortimer, September 8, 2010] {{DEFAULTSORT:Mortimer, John Jay}} [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:St. Mark's School (Massachusetts) alumni]] [[Category:Mortimer family of New York]] [[Category:Businesspeople from New York City]]

revision.comment: /* The top fifty producers in 2017 by sales */
revision.text:
[[File:Ludwigshafen Friedrich-Engelhorn-Hochhaus 20100709.jpg|thumb|upright|The [[Friedrich-Engelhorn-Hochhaus]], headquarters of BASF from 1957 to 2013]] ''[[Chemical & Engineering News]]'' publishes an annual '''list of the world's largest chemical producers''' by sales, excluding formulated products such as [[pharmaceutical drug]]s and [[coating]]s. In 2017, sales of the top fifty companies amounted to {{Currency|851.0 billion|US}}, an increase of 14.3% compared to the top fifty producers of 2016.{{Cite news|url=https://cen.acs.org/business/finance/CENs-Global-Top-50-chemical/96/i31|title=C&EN’s Global Top 50 chemical companies|last=Tullo|first=Alexander H.|date=30 July 2018|work=Chemical & Engineering News|access-date=8 October 2018|publisher=[[American Chemical Society]]}} The [[American Chemistry Council]] estimated that global chemical sales in 2014 rose by 3.7% to {{Currency|5.389 trillion|US}}.{{cite news |last=Davis |first=Nigel |date=7 September 2015 |title=ICIS Top 100 Chemical Companies |newspaper=ICIS Chemical Business |publisher=[[Reed Business Information]]}} In 2017, [[BASF]] was the world's largest chemical producer for the twelfth year in a row. In 2017, More than half of the companies on the list were headquartered in the United States (twelve), Japan (eight) or Germany (six); eighteen countries in total were represented. In 2017, Forty-eight of the companies on the list disclosed chemical profits, which totaled {{Currency|108.6 billion|US}}, an increase of 10.6% from 2016. The average [[profit margin]] for chemical operations for these companies was 13.4%. ==The top fifty producers in 2017 by sales== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" |- ! than any other company. The other companies that have headed the list are Dow Chemical, [[Hoechst AG|Hoechst]] (which merged with [[Rhône-Poulenc]] in 1999 and is now a subsidiary of [[Sanofi]]), [[Imperial Chemical Industries|ICI]] (acquired by AkzoNobel in 2008) and Bayer. {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" |- ! revision.text: {{Infobox person |name=Luiza Trajano |image=Luiza_Helena_Trajano.jpg |birth_date={{birth date and age|1951|10|09}} |birth_place= [[Franca]], [[São Paulo (state)|São Paulo]] |nationality= Brazilian |spouse=Erasmo Fernandes Rodrigues (a 2009) |children=Ana Luiza Trajano, [[Frederico Trajano]], Luciana Trajano |alma_mater=[[Faculdade de Direito de Franca]] |occupation=[[Chairwoman]] of [[Magazine Luiza]] |}} '''Luiza Helena Trajano Inácio Rodrigues''' (born October 9, 1951) is a Brazilian businessperson and billionaire. She is the chairwoman of the retail chain [[Magazine Luiza]] and other companies integrated with her holding company.{{Cite web|url=http://www.jusbrasil.com.br/diarios/40312569/dosp-cidade-06-09-2012-pg-109|title=Concessão do Título de "Cidadã Paulistana" a Luiza Helena Trajano Inácio Rodrigues.|date=06/09/2012|publisher=}}{{Cite web|url=http://ultimosegundo.ig.com.br/os-60-mais-poderosos/luiza-trajano/5202d62f9c9d9af340000008.html|title=Perfil de Luiza Helena Trajano|date=|publisher=}} == Life == Trajano was born in [[Franca]], in the state of São Paulo. She graduated in law from the Faculdade de Direito de Franca in 1972. Her uncle and aunt, Pelegrino José Donato and Luiza Trajano Donato had a retail store in Franca, named Magazine Luiza. {{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-10-10/murdered-worker-spurs-brazil-mogul-s-crusade-over-abuse-of-women|title=Murdered Worker Spurs Brazil Mogul's Crusade Over Abuse of Women|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-11-05}}She worked on the firm through several sectors, such as collection and sales, before becoming the company's director-superintendent, in 1991. [http://epocanegocios.globo.com/Revista/Common/0,,ERT63100-16645,00.html Virtude rende lucros]. [[Época Negócios]], edição de março de 2009 (especial de aniversário), p. 74 Under her command, Magazine Luiza became a chain of more than 800 stores, spread into 16 Brazilian states.{{Cite web|url=https://www.weforum.org/people/luiza-h-trajano-i-rodrigues|title=Luiza Helena Trajano|website=World Economic Forum|access-date=2018-11-05}} Trajano also leads Grupo Mulheres do Brasil (Women of Brazil Group), formed in 2012 by 50 Brazilian women entrepreneurs. Today, they are more than 4,000 and meet every month to discuss and propose actions related to education, entrepreneurship, social projects and gender equality in the workforce, supporting quotas for women.{{Cite web|url=https://revistamarieclaire.globo.com/Noticias/noticia/2017/06/mulheres-do-brasil-por-um-pais-melhor.html|title=Mulheres do Brasil: projeto liderado por Luiza Trajano para pensar o país|date=26 de junho de 2017|website=Marie Claire}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Trajano, Luiza Helena}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:People from Franca]] [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Brazilian businesspeople]] [[Category:Brazilian billionaires]]

{{Infobox officeholder | name = Lyon Gardiner Tyler | image = Lyon Gardiner Tyler in academic dress.jpg | caption = Tyler circa 1915 | order = 17th | title = [[List of presidents of the College of William & Mary|President of the
College of William & Mary]] | term_start = 1888 | term_end = 1919 | predecessor = [[Benjamin Stoddert Ewell]] | successor = [[J. A. C. Chandler]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1853|8|24}} | birth_place = [[Charles City County, Virginia]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1935|2|12|1853|8|24}} | death_place = [[Richmond, Virginia]] | alma_mater = [[University of Virginia]] | spouse = Anne Baker Tucker (died 1921)
Sue Ruffin | children = 6 | parents = [[John Tyler]]
[[Julia Gardiner Tyler]] }} '''Lyon Gardiner Tyler Sr.''' (August 24, 1853 – February 12, 1935) was an American [[educator]], genealogist, and [[historian]]. He was the son of [[John Tyler]], 10th [[President of the United States]]. He was [[List of presidents of the College of William & Mary|17th president]] of the [[College of William and Mary]], an advocate of historical research and preservation, and a prominent critic of US President [[Abraham Lincoln]]. Two of his own children are still alive, making President Tyler by far the oldest President to have living grandchildren. ==Biography== ===Early life and career=== [[File:Lyon Gardiner Tylor.jpg|thumb|left|Lyon Gardiner Tyler as a young man]] Tyler was the fourth son of President [[John Tyler]] and First Lady [[Julia Gardiner Tyler]], born at [[Sherwood Forest Plantation]]. When he was eight, his father died, and this coupled with the beginning of the [[American Civil War]] prompted the family to move north to [[Staten Island]], where his mother's family was from. He returned to Virginia in 1869 to earn both a bachelor's degree and a master's degree in law from the [[University of Virginia]], graduating in 1875. While at the University he was a member of [[Kappa Sigma]] and Jefferson Literary Society, and was recognized for his contributions to the school's literary magazine.{{cite encyclopedia |author= |coauthors= |editor= |encyclopedia=[[Encyclopedia Virginia]] |title=Lyon Gardiner Tyler (1853–1935) |url= http://www.encyclopediavirginia.org/Tyler_Lyon_Gardiner_1853-1935 |isbn= |accessdate=2016-11-14 }} Upon graduation, Tyler spent a year teaching philosophy and literature at the College of William and Mary, but as the school was struggling financially it ceased being able to pay his salary, whereupon he resigned and moved to [[Memphis, Tennessee]], where he spent several years as principal of a private school. In 1882 he returned to Virginia to practice law in [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]]. With the support of his mother, who lived there at the time, he began work on ''The Letters and Times of the Tylers'', a three-volume study of the careers of his father and paternal grandfather, [[John Tyler Sr.]]. This would be published between 1884 and 1896. During his life in Richmond, Tyler became a prominent advocate for public education reform. He helped to revive the [[Virginia Mechanics Institute]], on whose board he served and at which institution he taught. In 1887 he was elected to the [[Virginia House of Delegates]], which gave him the opportunity to lobby for money for the College of William and Mary; he procured $10,000 to restore the school, which had lain dormant for seven years due to lack of funding and the ravages of war. This advocacy allowed the College to reopen in 1888; Tyler was named its president. ===At William and Mary=== From 1888 to 1919, Tyler served as the [[List of presidents of the College of William & Mary|17th president]] of the [[College of William and Mary]] (W&M); he is widely credited for restoring the college's financial condition following the deterioration which took place in the wake of the [[American Civil War]]. During his tenure he held the chairmanship of the history department, and with six other professors formed the body known as the "[[Seven Society (College of William & Mary)#Tyler and The Seven Wise Men|Seven Wise Men]]". He also was responsible for the creation of the ''[[William and Mary Quarterly]]'' journal. An advocate of women's suffrage, he oversaw the College when it became the first in the Commonwealth of Virginia to admit women, in 1918.{{cite web|url=https://scdbwiki.swem.wm.edu/wiki/index.php?title=Lyon_Gardiner_Tyler_(1853-1935)|title=Lyon Gardiner Tyler (1853–1935) – Special Collections Wiki|publisher=|accessdate=14 November 2016}} It was while at the College that Tyler became interested in the [[history of Virginia]]; he would eventually conduct research throughout the state, and campaigned for the preservation of local records. In 1896 he managed to persuade the [[Virginia General Assembly]] to appropriate $5,000 for the copying of 17th-century court records, an action which set a precedent for the expenditure of public monies to preserve state records. Such preservation became his mission in later years, and he traveled extensively throughout the Commonwealth to find material. In 1915 he was elected to the State Library Board, serving until his death; he was a member of the [[Virginia Historical Society]] for fifty-two years, spending forty-seven of those on its executive committee and thirty-two as a vice president. He was a prolific author, and his work spurred recognition of the significance of both [[Jamestown, Virginia|Jamestown]] and [[Williamsburg, Virginia|Williamsburg]] to American history. He also spent much of his career attempting to rehabilitate his father's political reputation.{{cite book|author=Edward P. Crapol|title=John Tyler, the Accidental President|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YlbqCQAAQBAJ&pg=PR17|date=18 January 2012|publisher=Univ of North Carolina Press|isbn=978-0-8078-8272-6|pages=17–}} ===Retirement and death=== Tyler resigned his presidency of William and Mary in June 1919; during his tenure the College had increased its enrollment to over 200 pupils. The number of faculty had grown to fourteen, and twelve buildings were either renovated or constructed. The school also became a public institution, an effort which he spearheaded himself.{{cite web|url=http://www.wm.edu/as/history/about/index.php|title=William & Mary- The Lyon Gardiner Tyler Department of History|publisher=|accessdate=14 November 2016}} He retired to his farm, Lion's Den, in Charles City County. He remained active in his profession, as a writer, speaker, and researcher, until dying of pneumonia on February 12, 1935 in Richmond,{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Dr. Lyon Tyler, 82, Dead in Richmond. Former Head of William and Mary |url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0D16FC3859107A93C1A81789D85F418385F9 |quote= |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29 }} where he is buried in [[Hollywood Cemetery (Richmond, Virginia)|Hollywood Cemetery]]. ===Criticism of Abraham Lincoln=== Tyler received a deal of notoriety during his career for his criticism of [[Abraham Lincoln]], which he expressed on numerous occasions. The first of these came in 1917 when in response to an editorial in the ''[[New York Times]]'' suggesting that Southern slaveholders were akin to the German aristocrats then causing trouble in Europe, Tyler posited that it was Lincoln who more closely resembled the Prussian nobility with his flouting of the [[Constitution of the United States|Constitution]] during the Civil War. Eleven years later the issue arose again when the Virginia House of Delegates chose to adjourn in honor of [[Lincoln's Birthday|Lincoln's birthday]]; Tyler contended that Lincoln was no hero and did not merit the honor. When [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] fired back that Tyler's father, compared to the later president, was a dwarf both in stature and in accomplishments, Tyler retorted with a pamphlet claiming that it was Lincoln who was the dwarf. He would go on in retirement to continue the crusade against Lincoln, publishing many articles in his own journal, ''Tyler's Quarterly and Genealogical Magazine'', that were highly critical of the sixteenth president.{{cite journal|url=http://quod.lib.umich.edu/j/jala/2629860.0024.104/--lincoln-the-dwarf-lyon-gardiner-tylers-war-on-the-mythical?rgn=main;view=fulltext|title=Lincoln the Dwarf: Lyon Gardiner Tyler's War on the Mythical Lincoln|first=Monroe,|last=Dan|date=1 January 2003|publisher=|volume=24|issue=1|accessdate=14 November 2016}} ===Personal life=== Tyler was married twice. His first wife was Anne Baker Tucker of [[Albemarle County, Virginia|Albemarle County]], with whom he had three children: John Tyler; Elizabeth Gilmer Tyler; and Julia Gardiner Tyler Wilson, one of the founders of [[Kappa Delta]]. Following Anne's death in 1921, he married the former Sue Ruffin, 35 years his junior, with whom he had a further three children: Lyon Gardiner Tyler, Jr. (born 1924);[http://www.franklinlionsclub.com/Tyler.html Lyon Gardiner Tyler, Jr.] from Franklin Lions Club Harrison Ruffin Tyler (born 1928); and Henry Tyler, who died in infancy.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} {{As of|2018|09}}, both surviving sons from Sue are still alive, making their grandfather the earliest former President of the United States with living grandchildren.{{cite web|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/29842/president-john-tylers-grandsons-are-still-alive|title=President John Tyler's Grandsons Are Still Alive|publisher=Mental Floss|author=John English|date=February 15, 2016|accessdate=May 4, 2016}} In late August 2018, Lyon, Jr. participated in a reunion of presidential descendants hosted by the White House Historical Association, and signed, along with other descendants, a drawer from a copy of the Resolute Desk.{{cite news |last1=McCarthy |first1=Ellen |title=‘No one talks about that. No, no no!’ At a reunion of presidential descendants, don’t ask about Trump. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/no-one-talks-about-that-no-no-no-at-a-reunion-of-presidential-descendants-dont-ask-about-trump/2018/08/30/832585e8-ac61-11e8-b1da-ff7faa680710_story.html?utm_term=.56a32ec2059e |accessdate=31 August 2018 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=30 August 2018}} ==Major works== [[File:Tyler Garden at the College of William & Mary (2150603535).jpg|thumb|Tyler Memorial Garden, dedicated to Lyon Gardiner Tyler, his father, and his grandfather]] Tyler's major works include: *''The Letters and Times of the Tylers'' (three volumes, 1884–1896) *''Parties and Patronage in the United States'' (1891) *''The Cradle of the Republic: Jamestown and the James River'' (1900) *''England in America'' (1904) *''Williamsburg, the Old Colonial Capital'' (1907) *''Men of Mark in Virginia'' (1906–1909) *''Encyclopedia of Virginia Biography'' (1915) *''History of Virginia from 1763 to 1861'' (1924) *''A Confederate Catechism'' (1929) ==Legacy== Lyon, Sr.'s personal papers{{cite web|title=Tyler Family Papers, Group B|url=http://scrc.swem.wm.edu/index.php?p=collections/controlcard&id=7000|publisher=Special Collections Research Center, Earl Gregg Swem Library, College of William and Mary|accessdate=22 January 2011}} and the papers from his time as President of the [[College of William and Mary]]{{cite web|title=Office of the President. Lyon Gardiner Tyler|url=http://scrc.swem.wm.edu/index.php?p=collections/controlcard&id=6650|publisher=Special Collections Research Center, Earl Gregg Swem Library, College of William and Mary|accessdate=22 January 2011}} can be found at the [[Earl Gregg Swem Library#Special Collections Research Center|Special Collections Research Center]]. Additionally, numerous memorials to Tyler exist on the William and Mary campus. Among these is the Tyler Family Garden, dedicated to Tyler as well as his father and paternal grandfather, both of whom were alumni of the College; located next to James Blair Hall, which houses the university's history department, the garden contains busts of the three men, and was dedicated on April 30, 2004. It was funded as part of a $5 million gift from Lyon's son, Harrison Ruffin Tyler, and his wife. In addition, the history department is now known as the Lyon Gardiner Tyler Department of History.{{cite web|url=https://www.wm.edu/as/history/news/2001-2005_archive/wm-dedicates-garden-in-honor-of-tyler-family-legacy.php|title=William & Mary- W&M Dedicates Garden in Honor of Tyler Family Legacy|publisher=|accessdate=14 November 2016}} ==See also== *[[Seven Society (College of William & Mary)]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{sisterlinks|d=Q6709631|c=Category:Lyon Gardiner Tyler|s=Author:Lyon Gardiner Tyler|n=no|b=no|v=no|voy=no|m=no|mw=no|species=no|wikt=no|q=no}} * {{Gutenberg author |id=Tyler,+Lyon+Gardiner | name=Lyon Gardiner Tyler}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Lyon Gardiner Tyler}} *[http://myweb.wvnet.edu/~jelkins/lp-2001/tyler_lyon2.html Russell Smith's Lyon G. Tyler and the Quest for a Dissertation] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080509105451/http://www.wm.edu/history/LyonGardinerTyler.php Lyon G. Tyler Department of History at the College of William and Mary] *[http://scrc.swem.wm.edu/index.php?p=collections/controlcard&id=6650 Finding aid for the Office of the President. Lyon Gardiner Tyler Records] *[http://scrc.swem.wm.edu/index.php?p=collections/controlcard&id=7000 Finding aid for the Tyler Family Papers, Group B] *{{findagrave|6654940}} {{College of William & Mary presidents}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tyler, Lyon Gardiner}} [[Category:1853 births]] [[Category:1935 deaths]] [[Category:John Tyler family|Lyon Gardiner Tyler]] [[Category:Gardiner family]] [[Category:Children of Presidents of the United States]] [[Category:University of Virginia alumni]] [[Category:19th-century American historians]] [[Category:20th-century American historians]] [[Category:19th-century American educators]] [[Category:20th-century American educators]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]] [[Category:19th-century male writers]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:American people of Dutch descent]] [[Category:American people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:Members of the Virginia House of Delegates]] [[Category:Presidents of the College of William & Mary]] [[Category:College of William & Mary faculty]] [[Category:People from Charles City County, Virginia]] [[Category:Burials at Hollywood Cemetery (Richmond, Virginia)]] [[Category:Deaths from pneumonia]] [[Category:Infectious disease deaths in Virginia]]

revision.text:
{{other uses}}
[[File:Tulsa Oklahoma Sister Cities Sign crop.jpg|thumb|right|sign for South Main Street, [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]]]] '''Main Street''' is a generic phrase used to denote a primary retail street of a [[village]], [[town]] or small city in many parts of the world. It is usually a focal point for [[Retailing#Shops and Stores|shop]]s and retailers in the [[central business district]], and is most often used in reference to retailing and socializing.
The term is commonly used in Ireland, Scotland, the United States, Canada, and less often in Australia and New Zealand. In most of the United Kingdom the common description is [[High Street]] though "[[Fore Street]]" or "Front Street" is commonplace in some regions. In [[Jamaica]] the term is Front Street.
In many places, the [[street name]] for such a street is actually "Main Street", though even where it isn't the term "Main street" is still used to describe the main thoroughfare of the central business district. The [[U.S. Highway 66 Association|"Main Street of America"]] branding was used to promote [[U.S. Route 66]] in its heyday.
==American cultural usage== [[File:Bastrop Texas1.jpg|thumb|right|A traditional Main Street; [[Bastrop, Texas]], featuring the small shops and old-fashioned architecture typical of rural towns]] In the general sense, the term "Main Street" refers to a place of traditional values. Social realists from 1870 to 1930 used the name as a symbol of stifling conformity.<ref>Ruth Ann Alexander, "Midwest Main Street in Literature: Symbol of Conformity," ''Rocky Mountain Social Science Journal'' (1968) 5#2 pp 1-12</ref> [[Sherwood Anderson]], for example, wrote ''[[Winesburg, Ohio]]: A Group of Tales of Ohio Small Town Life'' in 1919. The best-selling 1920 novel ''[[Main Street (novel)|Main Street]]'' was a critique of small town life, by the American writer [[Sinclair Lewis]]. The locale was "Gopher Prairie," presented as an 'ideal type' of the Midwestern town, and the heroine, Carol Kennicott, was a more urbane, 'ideal-typical' Progressive.<ref>Hans-Jürgen Grabbe, "The Ideal Type of the Small Town: 'Main Street' in a Social Science Context," ''Amerikastudien'' (1987) 32#2 pp 181-190.</ref>
In North American media of later decades, "Main Street" represents the interests of everyday people and [[small business]] owners, in contrast with "[[Wall Street]]" (in the United States) or "[[Bay Street]]" (in Canada), symbolizing the interests of large national corporations. Thus, in the 1949 movie adaptation of [[On the Town (film)|''On The Town'']], the song "When You Walk Down Main Street With Me" refers to small-town values and social life. [[Main Street Republicans]], for example, see themselves as supporting those values as against urbane or "Wall Street" tendencies.
"Main Street" is part of the [[iconography]] of American life. For example, the [[Army and Air Force Exchange Service]], the outfit that operates the PX and BX stores on military bases, chose the name "Main Street USA" for its food courts.
''Main Street'' was a popular term during the economic crises in 2008 and 2009: [[Proposed bailout of U.S. financial system (2008)|the proposed bailout of U.S. financial system]], the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 US presidential campaign]], and [[United States presidential election debates, 2008|debates]]. One widely reviewed book was ''Bailout: An Inside Account of How Washington Abandoned Main Street While Rescuing Wall Street'' (2012) by [[Neil Barofsky]].
In small towns across the United States, Main Street is not only the major road running through town but the site of all street life, a place where townspeople hang out and watch the annual parades go by. A slang term popularized in the early 20th century, "main drag", is also used to refer to a town's main street.
===Walt Disney===
Two [[Walt Disney Company]] [[theme park]]s, [[Disneyland]] in Anaheim, California, and the [[Magic Kingdom]] in the [[Walt Disney World Resort]] near Orlando, Florida, both have "[[Main Street, U.S.A.]]" sections immediately at their front. These areas, which are designed to look like the main street of a small town, house gift shops, restaurants and various services, along with park offices on the second floors. While the architecture of these "streets" appears to be turn-of-the-20th-century, in fact these are decorative false-fronts on [[Industrial Style|industrial-style]] buildings. Main Street, U.S.A. is also present at [[Disneyland Paris]] and [[Hong Kong Disneyland]]. At [[Tokyo Disneyland]] the area is named "World Bazaar," but has the same look as Main Street, albeit housed under a decorative glass roof for protection from Japan's unpredictable weather.
Disney's design copied visual elements of small-town America seen in films by [[Frank Capra]] and others, in a deliberate attempt to capture the iconic symbolism of small-town America. Disney wanted to embed the values and memories associated with life in small towns into an entertainment experience for tourists.<ref>Robert Neuman, "Disneyland's Main Street, USA, and its Sources in Hollywood, USA," ''Journal of American Culture'' (2008) 31#1 pp 83-97, online</ref>
===Preservation and Main Street=== [[National Trust for Historic Preservation#National Trust Main Street Center|Main Street Inc.]] is the name of a community revitalization program begun by the [[National Trust for Historic Preservation]] in the late 1970s. The core of the Main Street philosophy is the preservation of the historic built environment by engaging in [[historic preservation]]. Main Street focuses on a holistic approach to revitalization based on the 4-point approach of design, promotion, economic restructuring, and organization. Originally targeted at small, traditional downtowns, the program has expanded to include towns of various sizes, including neighborhood districts in several large urban centers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mainstreet.org/|title=Home Page|date=2009-04-09|work=Main Street|publisher=National Main Street Center}}</ref>
In many communities, a merchants' association or [[business improvement district]] serves a promotional role on behalf of the merchants of a downtown Main Street. Individual city governments also may engage in revitalisation or historic preservation efforts to support a downtown core, either to make a community appear more attractive for [[tourism]] or to stem a flow of commerce out of the city into [[suburb]]s with [[shopping mall]]s and cookie-cutter [[big box store]]s.
In the [[United States of America|United States]] federal funds are allocated specifically for restoration of historic properties on the former [[U.S. Route 66]], the main street of many roadside towns; this funding is administered by the US [[National Park Service]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/nr/travel/route66/listofsites66.html|title=Discover Our Shared Heritage Travel Itinerary: Route 66|publisher=US [[National Park Service]]}}</ref>
== International use and equivalents ==
* Many small Canadian cities and towns have a thoroughfare named Main Street (or, in French, ''Rue principale''); in other cases, the main street of the community has a name particular to that community. The phrase "a town where the main street is still called Main Street" is occasionally used as being synonymous with small-town values. ** In [[Ottawa]], main streets of various individual [[village]]s which had been annexed to the larger urban municipality bear names like "Manotick Main" or "Osgoode Main" to distinguish them from Smyth Road (which becomes "Main Street" in one small area southeast of downtown Ottawa) and from each other. The actual main street of centretown Ottawa is [[Bank Street (Ottawa)|Bank Street]]. ** In [[Toronto]], Main Street is a mostly residential avenue in the [[East York]] district.<ref name=ShapingToronto/><ref name=RailsAcross/><ref name=MikeFileyTheWayWeWere2008/> At one time it was the main street of the hamlet of [[East Toronto]], which was annexed by the city of Toronto in 1908. It has kept its historic name, and evidence of its commercial origins can be seen in the stores at the corner of Main and Gerrard Streets. Toronto's main street is considered to be [[Yonge Street]], which divides the city's latitudinal streets into east-west. ** [[Saint Laurent Boulevard]], which divides [[Montreal]] between east and west, is unofficially known as "the Main." ** Main Street in [[Vancouver]] is a neighbourhood shopping street, near the dividing line between east and west side of town. However, the city's main city centre shopping street is Robson Street. * In [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]], smaller urban centres often have a main street. In some towns this street is officially designated Main Street or High Street; rarer variants include Main Road, Commercial Road, and Commerce Street. Often, though, the street is given a name peculiar to the town. For many small towns, the main street forms part of the principal road into, or through, the town. Large centres often have a [[central business district]] in which no one street is a clear focus for commercial activity, though for historical or cultural reasons there is often one street regarded as the city's "main street". Examples include [[Melbourne]]'s [[Collins Street, Melbourne|Collins Street]], [[Sydney]]'s [[George Street, Sydney|George Street]], [[Adelaide]]'s King William Street, [[Auckland]]'s Queen Street, and [[Christchurch]]'s [[Colombo Street]]. * In [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] most towns have a "main street", and this is usually the term given colloquially (for example, in offering road directions), though the primary thoroughfare of cities are often named after an historical figure, e.g. [[O'Connell Street]]. A more recent phenomenon in the media and with younger people is the misapplication of the term "high street" to describe typical or average street level fashion—likely due to advertising by various British retail multiples which began operating in Ireland during the "Celtic Tiger" years. * In [[England]], the terms "Market Street" or "Market Place" are often used to designate the heart of a town or city,{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} as is the more common High Street (particularly in newer urban developments, or towns or cities which were not original market towns). [[High Street]] is often the name of a fairly busy street with small shops on either side, often in towns and villages. * In [[Germany]], the [[Hauptstraße (allgemein)|Hauptstraße]] (literally "Main Street") is a highly trafficked street. Hauptstraßen even have formal recognition in road construction guidelines, which specify the width of lanes, for example. The term chiefly refers to motorized traffic, whereas "Einkaufsstraße" (shopping street) or "Fußgängerzone" (pedestrian district) refer to retail in the sense of Engl. "Main Street". * In [[Sweden]] and [[Norway]], almost all towns and cities have their own main street, a street called ''Storgatan''/''Storgaten'' (literally, "The big street"). They are typically surrounded by stores and restaurants, and increasingly since the late-20th century open for [[pedestrian]]s only. Likewise, in both [[Sweden]] and [[Norway]] this type of street is called ''gågata''/''gågate'' (literally, "walkingstreet"). * In most [[Comune|Italian municipalities]], the highway or another major route is called ''Via [[Rome|Roma]]''. This was done at the behest of [[Benito Mussolini]], who gave the order in 1939 to commemorate the [[March on Rome]]. * ''[[Jalan Besar]]'' (roughly translated from [[Malay language|Malay]] as "Main Road") is a common street name used in [[Malaysia]] (and to a more limited extent, [[Singapore]]) when referring to main streets of older urban centres in the country. Such main streets were originally constructed during British colonisation of territories in present-day Malaysia and Singapore, and were named in English as "Main Street" or "Main Road", depending on the size and nature of the urban centre, and often are laid out as parts of major thoroughfares between larger towns and cities. ** The independence of states that would form Malaysia and the introduction of the [[Malay language]] as the country's national language in 1967 led to extensive renaming of certain Main Streets or Main Roads to "''Jalan Besar''" in Malaysia the following decades. Large cities (such as [[List of capitals in Malaysia|state capitals]]) tend to forgo the use of "Main Street" or "Main Road" altogether as commercial or transport activity may be concentrated along more than one street. * In [[South Africa]], Main Road is the term used for the same concept as Main Street in the U.S. and High Street in the UK. * In [[Rural Khmer house|Cambodia]], the Main Road is between the Rice fields and settlements. * In [[Industrial engineering|Industrial Engineering]], "Main Street" is often used to describe a conveyor which transports the fundamental materials for producing objects to the automated construction site where the intended object will be assembled.
== Gallery ==
<gallery> File:Antal Berkes Foutca.jpg|Main street ({{lang-hu|Főutca}}, literally "Principal Street") in [[Budapest]], [[Hungary]] (by [[Antal Berkes]]) File:Main Street Bldg Chesterton IN 2012.jpg|Main Street in [[Chesterton, Indiana]] File:Belfast, Maine.jpg|Main Street, [[Belfast, Maine]] File:Manch-DownTown.jpg|Elm Street, [[Manchester, New Hampshire]], is the "main street" of the downtown central business district. File:Pan-American Highway-Mancora, PeruR.jpg|The main street in the [[Peru]]vian town of [[Máncora]], which happens to be the [[Pan-American Highway]]. File:Baylis Street, Wagga Wagga.jpg|Baylis Street, the Main Street of [[Wagga Wagga|Wagga Wagga, New South Wales]] File:Cullinan.jpg|The Main Street of [[Cullinan, Gauteng|Cullinan]], [[South Africa]] File:GPO flushing 11301 jeh.JPG|Looking across [[Main Street, Queens|Main Street]] in [[Queens, New York]], United States, at a post office. All five boroughs of New York City have streets named "Main Street", but this is the only one that is an [[arterial road]]. </gallery>
== See also == {{col-begin}}{{col-break|width=40%}} * [[Electric Avenue]] * [[High Street]] * [[List of Main Street Programs in the United States]] * [[Middletown studies]] * [[Main Street, U.S.A.]] * [[Shopping mall]] {{col-break|width=40%}} * [[Side road]] * [[Strip mall]] * [[Town]] * [[Wall Street]] * [[Will it play in Peoria?]] {{col-end}}
==References== {{reflist| refs= <ref name=ShapingToronto> {{cite book | url = http://www.torontotransforms.com/home-about-torontos-transformations/chapter-3-shaping-the-old-city/ | title = Toronto: Transformations in A City and its Region | publisher = [[University of Pennsylvania]] | author = Edward Relph | date = 2014 | page = | location = | isbn = | archiveurl = | archivedate = | accessdate = 2014-02-20 | deadurl = No | quote = The names of many of the old municipalities have been preserved in business improvement areas, and, for example, Main Street subway station refers to the main street of East Toronto. }} </ref> <ref name=RailsAcross> {{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=mAIc1st_CQMC&pg=PA19 | title = Rails Across Ontario: Exploring Ontario's Railway Heritage | publisher = [[Dundurn Press]] | author = Ron Brown | date = 2013 | page = 19 | location = | isbn = 9781459707542 | quote = Many wonder why there is a "Main Street" in Toronto's east end. This too came about when the GT selected a tract of land to create another sea of railway sidings. While it named its yard "York," the town that grew nearby was incorporated as "East Toronto" and the commercial main street became "Main Street." }} </ref> <ref name=MikeFileyTheWayWeWere2008> {{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ToQcKz0DFM4C&pg=PA209 | title = Toronto: The Way We Were | publisher = [[Dundurn Press]] | author = [[Mike Filey]] | date = 2008 | page = 209 | isbn = 9781550028423 | accessdate = 2014-02-20 | quote = One remnant of the ancient hamlet was the retention of the name of one of its original thoroughfares. That's why there's still a Main Street several miles east of Yonge, Toronto's original main street. }} </ref> }}
==Further reading== * Orvell, Miles. ''The Death and Life of Main Street: Small Towns in American Memory, Space, and Community'' (University of North Carolina Press; 2012) * Poll, Ryan. "Main Street and Empire: The Fictional Small Town in the Age of Globalization." New Brunswick, NJ: Rutgers University Press, 2012.
===Primary sources=== *Davies, Richard et al., eds. ''A Place Called Home: Writings on the Midwestern Small Town'' (2003) [https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0873514513 34 selections of cultural history, fiction, and poetry, both classic and contemporary]
==External links== {{commons category|Main Street}} * [http://www.mappingmainstreet.org/ Mapping Main Street] - a collaborative documentary media project that creates a new map of the country through stories, photos and videos recorded on actual Main Streets * Schneider-Cowan, Joy. [http://ecommons.txstate.edu/arp/268 "A Case Study of the San Marcos Main Street Program"] (2007). Applied Research Projects. Texas State University. Paper 268.
