revision.text:
'''MidAmerica Industrial Park''' is Oklahoma's largest industrial park. The park is located in [[Pryor Creek, Oklahoma]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.maip.com/overview.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-11-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120921185254/http://www.maip.com/overview.php |archivedate=2012-09-21 |df= }}. MidAmerica Industrial Park Website-Overview</ref> Over 70 firms are located within the industrial park including operations of seven [[Fortune 500]] companies.<ref>http://www.maip.com/midamerica/documents/Overview-MidAmComp.pdf. MidAmerica Industrial Park Website-Company Characteristics</ref> The park was founded in 1960, when the Federal government sold most of the former [[Oklahoma Ordnance Works]] to a public trust, the Oklahoma Ordnance Works Authority.<ref name ="EOHC-OOW">[http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/entries/O/OK069.html] Everett, Dianna. ''Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture''. "Oklahoma Ordinance Works. Retrieved February 23, 2013."</ref> It covers 9,000 acres (36 km²).<ref name="Small-town Pryor ">{{cite web| url=http://tulsaworld.com/news/article.aspx?articleID=070407_1_A1_hNews42637| title=Small-town Pryor getting some big hits| publisher=Tulsa World: tulsaworld.com| accessdate=2007-04-07| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070811123505/http://tulsaworld.com/news/article.aspx?articleID=070407_1_A1_hNews42637| archivedate=2007-08-11| df=}}</ref>
==Recent expansion== '''Urgent Care of Green Country''' [https://web.archive.org/web/20090330000846/http://www.urgentcaregc.com/urgent_care_families/index.htm] Urgent Care of Green Country (UCGC) opened their Pryor / MidAmerica clinic at MidAmerica Industrial Park on January 19, 2009. Independently owned, UCGC was founded in 2002 by Dr. Stephen R. Kovacs, D.O., F.A.B.H.P. and Dr. S.Addison Beeson, D.O., F.A.B.E.P. The {{convert|4400|sqft|m2|adj=on}} facility includes a reception area, doctor's office, eight exam / treatment rooms, EMR (Electronic Medical Records), in-house x-ray, orthopedics and lab services. The clinic will treat employees from MidAmerica industries and area businesses that require occupational health services such as: in-depth diagnostic and treatment for most occupational injuries; drug testing; employee physicals; and, sports physicals. Additionally, UCGC offers “walk-in treatment” with no appointment necessary for the general public from throughout Mayes County.
'''Tulsa Life Flight''', [http://www.tulsalifeflight.com/] a helicopter ambulance service formerly based solely at Saint Francis Hospital in Tulsa, will open a second base of operations at MidAmerica Industrial Park’s airport. Tulsa Life Flight was established in 1979. It was the thirteenth helicopter air ambulance to be established in the US and the first in Oklahoma. To date, Tulsa Life Flight has completed more than 42,200 accident free flights which is a record held only by a few programs in the world. The aircraft are owned and operated by Air Methods Corporation, the largest air ambulance corporation in the world. The firm contracts with Saint Francis Hospital to provide aircraft, pilots and mechanics.
The MidAmerica Industrial park is also home to a branch of [[Oklahoma State University–Okmulgee|OSU Institute of Technology]], which has some of the classes that OSU Institute of Technology provides. The [[MidAmerica Industrial Park Airport]] is also located in the park.
MidAmerica publishes a quarterly newsletter called MidPoint to share "news, views and other information" about the park and the industries that we serve. A complimentary subscription is available to individuals who are involved in site selection decision making for their respective companies. [https://web.archive.org/web/20090131225625/http://www.maip.com/news.php]
==New leadership== In November 2012, Oklahoma Governor [[Mary Fallin]] appointed David Stewart as the chief administrative officer of the Oklahoma Ordnance Works Authority (OOWA). He succeeded Sanders Mitchell, who had headed the authority for 35 years before retiring. Stewart was formerly president and chief executive officer (CEO) of Cherokee Nation Businesses LLC and the wholly owned parent/holding company of the Cherokee Nation, which is charged with the economic development and business diversification across the Cherokee Nation's business entities.<ref>McNutt, Michael. News OK. "New head of MidAmerica Industrial Park is named."November 30, 2012. Retrieved February 25, 2013.[http://newsok.com/new-head-of-midamerica-industrial-park-is-named/article/3733146]</ref> Sanders Mitchell had been hired by OOWA in 1977 to serve as general manager of the industrial park. He was promoted to the position of general manager for OOWA in 1990, following the death of the original chief administrative office, board member and founder of the Mid-America Industrial Park, Gene R. Redden, who served in this capacity from its inception in 1961 until his death in 1990. {{efn|Redden had come to OOWA in 1947 as its first general manager. He, along with the Pryor Chamber of Commerce and other local leaders convinced the Oklahoma state government to buy the Oklahoma Ordnance Works and turn it into an industrial park.<ref name EOHC-"OOW">[http://www.okhistory.org/publications/enc/entry.php?entry=OK069 Everett, Dianna. "Oklahoma Ordnance Works." ''Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture''.] Accessed January 20, 2017.</ref>}}<ref>''Pryor Times''. "Mitchell announces retirement from MAIP." March 13, 2012. Retrieved February 27, 2013.[http://pryordailytimes.com/local/x1284935694/Mitchell-announces-retirement-from-MAIP]</ref>
==Notes== {{notelist}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.maip.com/ MidAmerica Industrial Park] ** [http://maip.com/index.php/about_us/overview Overview] ** [http://maip.com/index.php/interactiveMap Industry Directory]
{{Coord|36|14|46|N|95|17|10|W|format=dms|display=title|type:city_region:US-OK}}

revision.text:
In [[quality management]], a '''nonconformity''' (sometimes referred to as a '''defect''') is a deviation from a [[Specification (technical standard)|specification]], a [[Technical standard|standard]], or an [[Expectation (epistemic)|expectation]]. Nonconformities can be classified in seriousness multiple ways, though a typical classification scheme may have three to four levels, including critical, serious, major, and minor.<ref name="HoyleISO09">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HWNWdBisJcoC&pg=PA691 |chapter=36. Corrective Action |title=ISO 9000 Quality Systems Handbook: Using the Standards as a Framework for Business Improvement |author=Hoyle, D. |publisher=Routledge |year=2009 |pages=687–704 |isbn=9781856176842}}</ref><ref name="BergerTheCert07">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3bYsth3j8eQC&pg=PA188 |chapter=Chapter 22 B. Material Control |title=The Certified Quality Engineer Handbook |editor1=Berger, R.W.|editor2=Benbow, D.W.|editor3=Elshannawy, A.K.|editor4=Walker, H.F. |publisher=ASQ Quality Press |year=2007 |pages=183–189 |isbn=9780873897006}}</ref><ref name="DorfTheTech98">{{cite book |title=The Technology Management Handbook |editor=Dorf, R.C. |publisher=CRC Press |year=1998 |pages=13-34 |isbn=9780849385773}}</ref><ref name="MitraFundamentals16">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pY_nCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT568 |chapter=Chapter 8: Control Charts for Attributes |title=Fundamentals of Quality Control and Improvement |author=Mitra, A. |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |year=2016 |isbn=9781118705445}}</ref>
While some situations allow "nonconformity" and "defect" to be used synonymously, some industries distinguish between the two; a nonconformity represents a failure to meet an intended state and specification, while a defect represents a failure to meet fitness for use/normal usage requirements.<ref name="BergerTheCert07" /> This can be seen in the international software engineering standard ISO/IEC 25010 (formerly [[ISO/IEC 9126]]), which defines a nonconformity as the nonfulfillment of a requirement and a [[Product defect|defect]] as the nonfulfillment of intended usage requirements.<ref name="ISO25010">{{cite web |url=https://www.iso.org/standard/35733.html |title=ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering -- Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) -- System and software quality models |publisher=International Organization for Standardization |date=March 2011 |accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref>
==Classifying nonconformity== When ensuring [[Quality (business)|quality]] of a product or a service, classification of a nonconformity is important, as it provides an opportunity to better reduce nonconformity.<ref name="HoyleISO09" /> Many quality management practices will do this using a relatively simple three- or four-level classification system.<ref name="BergerTheCert07" /><ref name="MitraFundamentals16" />For example, U.S. federal agencies such as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration have used a simple three-tier system for quality requirements of government-acquired supplies and services: minor, major, and critical nonconformance.<ref name="GSAFAR05">{{cite web |url=https://www.acquisition.gov/sites/default/files/current/far/pdf/FAR.pdf |format=PDF |title=Federal Acquisition Regulation |volume=1 |publisher=General Services Administration |page=46.103 |date=March 2005 |accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref> However, some industries may develop their own, custom ranking systems. An example from the [[automotive industry]] uses a 10-point system for finer granularity, where, for example, a one represents "none" (no effect), a six "moderate" (vehicle or item operable, but comfort or convenience items inoperable), and a 10 "hazardous without warning" (when a potential failure mode affects safe vehicle operation without warning).<ref name="HoyleISO09" /> Regardless of size, these classification schemes exist to help drive discovery and correction of nonconformities (and defects).<ref name="HoyleISO09" /><ref name="MitraFundamentals16" />
==Sources of nonconformity== The causes of nonconformities aren't unlimited and therefore determinable. Common causes for deficiencies to arise include<ref name="HoyleISO09" />:
* poor communication (or miscommunication) * poor documentation (or lack of documentation) * poor or limited training of personnel * poor motivation of personnel * poor quality materials (or lack of appropriate materials) * poor quality tools and equipment (or lack of appropriate tools and equipment) * poor or dysfunctional operating environment
== References == <references />
[[Category:ISO standards]] [[Category:Pharmaceutical industry]] [[Category:Quality management]]

[[Image:RaschigRings005.JPG|thumb|right|250px|Raschig rings one inch (25 mm) ceramic]] '''Raschig rings''' are pieces of tube, approximately equal in length and diameter, used in large numbers as a [[packed bed]] within columns for [[distillation column|distillation]]s and other [[chemical engineering]] processes. They are usually ceramic or metal and provide a large surface area within the volume of the column for interaction between liquid and gas vapours. Raschig rings are named after their inventor, the German chemist [[Friedrich Raschig]].<ref name=Sella>{{cite journal | author = Andrea Sella | year = 2008 | work = Chemistry World | volume = 5 | issue = 9 | pages = 83 | title = Raschig's Rings | url = http://www.rsc.org/chemistryworld/Issues/2008/September/RaschigsRings.asp}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Product description: Ceramic Raschig Ring|url=http://www.chemicalpackings.com/product/ceramic-raschig-ring.html|website=LianChuang|date=15 July 2016}}</ref>
==Use== They form what is now known as random packing, and enabled Raschig to perform distillations of much greater efficiency than his competitors using [[fractional distillation]] columns with trays.<ref name=Sella/>
In a distillation column, the [[reflux]] or condensed vapour runs down the column, covering the surfaces of the rings, while vapour from the [[reboiler]] goes up the column. As the vapour and liquid pass each other countercurrently in a small space, they tend towards equilibrium. Thus, less volatile material tends to go downwards, and more volatile material upwards.
They are also used for devices where gas and liquid are put in contact for purposes of gas absorption, stripping or chemical reaction, and as a support for [[biofilm]]s in biological reactors.
Raschig rings made from [[borosilicate glass]] are sometimes employed in the handling of nuclear materials, where they are used inside vessels and tanks containing solutions of fissile material, for example solutions of enriched [[uranyl nitrate]], acting as neutron absorbers and preventing a potential [[criticality accident]].<ref >[http://www.orau.org/ptp/collection/Miscellaneous/raschigrings.htm Oak Ridge Associated Universities] Raschig Rings for Criticality Control (1980s)</ref>
== Developments == Given the success of the simply-shaped Raschig ring, there have been many other forms developed in an attempt to either improve upon it, or to avoid patents for particular designs.
=== Pall ring === The Pall ring attempts to increase the useful aspects of packing, by giving an increased number of edges to disrupt flow, whilst also reducing the volume taken up by the ring packing medium itself. Rather than using a solid-walled tube, the Pall ring resembles an open basket structure of thin bars. These form both a tube and also a radial structure of cross bars.<ref >{{Cite web |title=Pall Ring |url=http://s341789233.online.de/editor/assets/Info%20RASCHIG%20Pall-Ring-350.pdf |website=Raschig-Jaeger Technologies }}</ref> Pall rings may be injection moulded of plastics, moulded of ceramics or press-formed from metal sheet.
=== Super ring === The Raschig 'Super Ring' represents a further development of the same concepts behind the Pall ring. It optimises the production of turbulent film-type flows and prevents the formation of drops.<ref >{{Cite web |title=Raschig Super-Ring |url=http://s341789233.online.de/editor/assets/Info%20RASCHIG%20Super-Ring-250.pdf |website=Raschig-Jaeger Technologies }}</ref> The 'rings' no longer resemble rings but are pressed from metal sheet in the form of wave shapes of narrow strips. Super rings appeared in 1995 and have been developed through several improved generations since.<ref >{{Cite journal |title=Raschig Super-Ring: A New Fourth Generation Packing Offers New Advantages |first=M. |last=Schultes |journal=Chemical Engineering Research and Design |volume=81 |issue=1 |date=January 2003 |pages=48–57 |doi=10.1205/026387603321158186 |conference=International Conference on Distillation and Absorption }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Fractionating column]] *[[Dixon rings]] *[[Random column packing]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Distillation]] [[Category:Industrial processes]]

revision.text:
{{Coord|35|54|29|N|78|51|46|W|type:city|display=title}} {{More citations needed|date=May 2007}} {{Infobox institute | name = Research Triangle Park | image = [[Image:2008-07-25 Research Triangle Park Headquarters.jpg|frameless|upright=1.2]] | caption = RTP headquarters at 12 Davis Drive | motto = Inspiring bold ideas | established = {{Start date|1959}} | location = Research Triangle Park, [[North Carolina]] | website = {{ URL | https://www.rtp.org/ }} }}
The '''Research Triangle Park''' ('''RTP''') is the largest [[Science park|research park]] in the United States.<ref name="AboutRTP">{{cite web|url=https://www.rtp.org/|title=The Research Triangle Park |publisher=Rtp.org |date= |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://medcitynews.com/2010/08/minneapolis-to-host-annual-conference-of-university-research-parks/ |title=Minneapolis to host annual conference of university research parks |publisher=MedCity News |date=2010-08-09 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www7.nationalacademies.org/ocga/testimony/Research_Parks_and_Job_Creation.asp |title=Research Parks and Job Creation: Innovation Through Cooperation |publisher=.nationalacademies.org |date=2009-12-09 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> It is named for the three hub cities of [[Raleigh, North Carolina|Raleigh]], [[Durham, North Carolina|Durham]], and [[Chapel Hill, North Carolina|Chapel Hill]], or more properly for the three major research universities in those three cities ([[NC State University]], [[Duke University]], and the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] respectively). The [[Research Triangle]] region of [[North Carolina]] received its name as an extension of the name of the park. Besides the three anchor cities, the park is also bounded by the communities of [[Morrisville, North Carolina|Morrisville]] and [[Cary, North Carolina|Cary]]. Approximately one fourth of the park's territory lies in [[Wake County, North Carolina|Wake County]], but the majority of its land is in [[Durham County, North Carolina|Durham County]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.waywelivednc.com/maps/historical/rtp.pdf|title=Research Triangle Park}}</ref>
==Overview== RTP is one of the most prominent [[high-tech]] [[research and development]] parks in the [[United States]]. It was created in 1959<ref>{{Citation |title=Travel North Carolina: Going Native in the Old North State |author1=Carolyn Sakowski |author2=Sue Clark |author3=Angela Harwood |author4=Steve Kirk |author5=Artie Sparrow |author6=Anne Holcomb Waters |edition=4 |publisher=John F. Blair |year=2010 |isbn=978-0-89587-379-8 | accessdate = 2011-12-14 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=S1S_YOXAEhgC&pg=PA273&dq=triangle+park+North+Carolina&hl=en&ei=VPPoTsfWEs2y8QORhLSFCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=triangle%20park%20North%20Carolina&f=false }}</ref> by state and local governments, nearby [[universities]], and local business interests. [[Karl Robbins]] bought the land where the park is now built. The park covers {{convert|7000|acre|ha|0}} situated in a [[pine]] [[forest]] with {{convert|22500000|sqft|m2|0}} of built space.<ref name="AboutRTP"/> The park is traversed by [[Interstate 40]]; the [[Durham Freeway]]; and [[NC 540]].
The park is home to over 200 companies employing 50,000 workers and 10,000 contractors,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsobserver.com/2010/09/04/663597/rtp-begins-updating-rules.html |title=RTP begins updating its master plan |last=Bracken |first=David |publisher=NewsObserver.com |date=2010-09-04 |accessdate=2018-11-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101012050104/http://www.newsobserver.com/2010/09/04/663597/rtp-begins-updating-rules.html |archive-date=2010-10-12 |df= |deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidkroll/2012/10/22/rtp-research-triangle-primer/ |title=RTP: Research Triangle Primer |publisher=Forbes |date=2012-04-18 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> including the second largest [[IBM]] operation in the world, smaller only than the one in [[IBM India|India]]; the company has around 14,000 employees in RTP.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www-01.ibm.com/employment/us/extremeblue/location/raleigh.html|title=United States}}</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2017}}
The park hosts one of [[GlaxoSmithKline]]'s largest R&D centers with approximately 5,000 employees.<ref>{{cite web|author=WRAL Tech Wire |url=http://wraltechwire.com/business/tech_wire/news/blogpost/9123243/ |title=GSK cutting positions in RTP, nationwide -TechWire Insider :: Editor's Blog at WRAL Tech Wire |publisher=Wraltechwire.com |date=2011-02-16 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> [[Cisco Systems]]' campus in RTP, with approximately 5,000 employees, is the second highest concentration of its employees outside of its Silicon Valley corporate headquarters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wral.com/business/story/9876837/ |title=Cisco to slash 6,500 workers; RTP impact unknown |publisher=WRAL.com |date=2011-07-18 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> The [[National Institute of Health]] has its [[National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences]] located in RTP and [[Durham, North Carolina|Durham]].
Research Triangle Park is owned and managed by the [[Research Triangle Foundation]],<ref>{{cite web |last=Chodavadia |first=Parth |url=https://www.dukechronicle.com/article/2012/11/research-triangle-park-develops-strategy-future-growth |title=Research Triangle Park develops strategy for future growth |newspaper=Duke Chronicle |date=2012-11-28 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> a private non-profit organization. In August 2017, Scott Levitan was named the organization's new President and CEO, making him the 9th leader since the foundation was established.
== History == Following World War II, North Carolina's economy could no longer depend upon their traditional industries of agriculture, textiles, and furniture; their market share was in decline and jobs were leaving. Academics at N.C. State and Duke came up with the idea of creating the park so that the universities could do research together, leverage the area's strengths, and keep graduates in state.<ref name="Our State Magazine">{{Cite news|url=https://www.ourstate.com/research-triangle-park/|title=The Man and Plan Behind Research Triangle Park – Our State Magazine|date=2014-08-25|work=Our State Magazine|access-date=2017-12-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
Established in 1951 and located in North Carolina, Research Triangle Park was created to increase innovation in the area. It is bordered by Duke University, North Carolina State University, and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. At first, the park struggled to recruit innovators, but in 1965, Research Triangle Park saw its largest surge of growth, thanks to heavy recruiting by the state's government and Archibald (Archie) Davis.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Link|first=Albert N.|last2=Scott|first2=John T.|date=2003|title=The Growth of Research Triangle Park|jstor=40229257|journal=Small Business Economics|volume=20|issue=2|pages=167–175|doi=10.2307/40229257}}</ref> In their article "The Growth of Research Triangle Park," Link and Scott posit that entrepreneurial culture and, especially, leadership contributed the most to its success as a cluster. Archie Davis promoted a culture of innovation and entrepreneurship by locating the park near universities, actively recruiting organizations (like the American Academy of Arts and Sciences), and used his vision to raise funding for the park.
Davis strongly believed that profits could not be the only driver for creating the park - the betterment of the community should be the key goal. "The love of this state … was the motivation for the Research Triangle idea," he said. "Research Triangle is a manifestation of what North Carolina is all about." Research Triangle Park remains a nonprofit.<ref name="Our State Magazine"/>
==Local government== The park is an [[unincorporated area]], and state law prohibits municipalities from annexing areas within the park.<ref>"Could RDU do more for Durham?", Raleigh News & Observer, 13-Sept-2009, p.13A</ref> Some local government functions are served by the Durham-Wake Counties Research and Production Service District, a special tax district created in 1986<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.durham-nc.com/resources/pdf/tourmap_drive.pdf|title=Self-Driving Tour of Research Triangle Park|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120401085734/http://www.durham-nc.com/resources/pdf/tourmap_drive.pdf|archivedate=2012-04-01|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://godoggo.org/files/maps/rtp.pdf|title=The Research Triangle Park Jogging & Pedestrian Trails}}</ref> that is conterminous with the park, wherein the property tax rate is limited to 10 cents per $100 valuation.<ref name="thertpblog.org">{{cite web |author=Choose RTP Park Life About RTP Contact Us Blog |url=http://thertpblog.org/2012/07/31/master-plan-update-legislative-changes-approved/ |title=Master Plan Update: Legislative Changes Approved |publisher=The RTP Blog |date=2012-07-31 |accessdate=2013-05-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819041459/http://thertpblog.org/2012/07/31/master-plan-update-legislative-changes-approved/ |archivedate=2012-08-19 |df= }}</ref> The park has special zoning as a Research Applications District in the Wake County portion, and a Scientific Research Park in the Durham County portion. As of October 2012, both zoning areas are in the process of being revised to allow higher density development.<ref>{{cite web |author=Choose RTP Park Life About RTP Contact Us Blog |url=http://thertpblog.org/2012/10/03/master-plan-update-zoning-gives-room-to-grow/ |title=Master Plan Update: Zoning Gives Room to Grow |publisher=The RTP Blog |date=2012-10-03 |accessdate=2013-05-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130415225733/http://thertpblog.org/2012/10/03/master-plan-update-zoning-gives-room-to-grow/ |archivedate=2013-04-15 |df= }}</ref> The zoning changes are coupled with legislative changes allowing for Urban Research Service Districts (URSD) within the Park, which can include a mix of retail and residential usages.<ref>{{cite web |last=Bracken |first=David |url=http://www.newsobserver.com/2012/07/16/2202530/new-rtp-master-plan-to-be-unveiled.html |title=New RTP master plan to be unveiled this fall | Local/State |publisher=NewsObserver.com |date=2012-07-16 |accessdate=2013-05-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502043553/http://www.newsobserver.com/2012/07/16/2202530/new-rtp-master-plan-to-be-unveiled.html |archivedate=2013-05-02 |df= }}</ref> These newly permitted URSDs could levy taxes at the same rate as a neighboring city.<ref name="thertpblog.org"/>
==Master Plan, Redevelopment, and Park Center== On October 1, 2015, former President and CEO of the Research Triangle Foundation, Bob Geolas, announced RTP's plans for a $50 million redevelopment involving the formation of "Park Center." $20 million will be allocated from Durham County, $10 million from the Durham-Wake Counties Research and Production Service District, and $20 million as a result of land purchases and site work provided by the Research Triangle Foundation of North Carolina.<ref>{{Cite web|title = RTP Reveals Park Center Plan - The Research Triangle Park|url = https://www.rtp.org/rtp-reveals-park-center-plan/|website = The Research Triangle Park|access-date = 2016-01-29|language = en-US}}</ref>
Park Center is to be over 300,000 square feet of public space at the heart of the Research Triangle Park. This public area will include retail outlets, food and beverage venues, and entertainment space. Geolas states that "We want to make all of this as local as possible. I would like to have as few chains, no chains if we could. I'd love for it all to be local. Local coffee, local food, local produce, local products."<ref>{{Cite web|title = Park Center Redevelopment|url = https://www.rtp.org/about-us/park-center/|website = The Research Triangle Park|access-date = 2016-01-29|language = en-US}}</ref>
The redevelopment plans also include exploring partnerships with regional transit groups. The hope of the Research Triangle Foundation is to broaden public transportation to and from the area. According to Geolas, "We are currently having discussions about bringing the Regional Transit Center over to Park Center so that we can connect with all of our transit links." A public commuter rail is also in talks.<ref>{{Cite web|title = RTP Announces $50M for Park Center Development|url = https://vimeo.com/141200953|website = Vimeo|access-date = 2016-01-29}}</ref>
== Subsidiaries of The Research Triangle Park Foundation == The Research Triangle Park Foundation operates three buildings within RTP. These three buildings are The Frontier, The Lab, and The Archie K. Davis Conference Center. The Frontier is a collaboration space that was first opened in January 2015. Since its inception, over 20,000 visitors have come through The Frontier's doors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rtp.org/about-us/the-frontier/|title=The Frontier|website=The Research Triangle Park|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-03}}</ref> The Lab is a full-service lab and office space that houses multiple [[Research and development|Research and Development]] companies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rtp.org/about-us/thelab/|title=The Lab - The Research Triangle Park|website=The Research Triangle Park|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-03}}</ref> The Archie K. Davis Conference Center is a 6,800-square-foot event space. The AKD Conference Center is also home to the Research Triangle Park Foundation main offices.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rtp.org/events/reserve-conference-room/|title=About The AKD Conference Center - The Research Triangle Park|website=The Research Triangle Park|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-03}}</ref>
==Universities in the Research Triangle area== {{Category see also|Universities and colleges in the Research Triangle}} *[[Norman Adrian Wiggins School of Law|Campbell University's Norman Adrian Wiggins School of Law]] *[[Duke University]] *[[Meredith College]] *[[North Carolina Central University]] *[[North Carolina State University]] *[[St. Augustine's University]] *[[Shaw University]] *[[Skema Business School]] *[[Strayer University]] *[[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] *[[William Peace University]]
==See also== *[[Megasite]] {{Commons category|Research Triangle Park}}
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==Bibliography== * {{cite book | title= A Generosity of Spirit: The Early History of the Research Triangle Park | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ZO6YAAAACAAJ | first= Albert N. | last= Link | year= 1995 | publisher= Research Triangle Foundation of North Carolina | location= Research Triangle Park | isbn= 978-0-9648051-0-1 | oclc= 33045964}} * {{cite book | title= From Seed to Harvest: The Growth of the Research Triangle Park | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=grSlAAAACAAJ | first= Albert N. | last= Link | year= 2002 | publisher= Research Triangle Foundation of North Carolina | location= Research Triangle Park | isbn= 978-0-9648051-1-8 | oclc= 50694901}}
==External links== * [https://www.rtp.org/ Research Triangle Park Web site] * [http://www.researchtriangle.org Research Triangle Regional Partnership] * [http://vimeo.com/11199745 North Carolina's Research Triangle Park: An Investment in the Future] UNC-TV documentary commemorating RTP's 40th anniversary, produced by John Wilson and narrated by Carl Kasell of NPR News

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Use British English|date=September 2016}} '''Robert Heller''' (10 June 1932 – 28 August 2012) was a British [[management]] [[journalist]], management consultant, [[author]] of a series of management books, and the founding editor of ''Management Today''.
== Biography == Born in London, Heller attended [[Christ's Hospital]] in the Sussex countryside, served in the [[Royal Army Service Corps]], and then attended [[Jesus College, Cambridge]], where he was awarded a double first in history.<ref name="DB 2012">David Brewerton (2012) "[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/sep/18/robert-heller Robert Heller obituary: Business journalist and author of a stream of books on management in which he explained the 'tricks of the trade']." in: ''The Guardian'', Tuesday 18 September 2012</ref>
In 1955 Heller started to work for the ''[[Financial Times]]'', where in 1958 he was made US correspondent. In 1963 he moved to become business editor of ''[[The Observer]]''.<ref name="DB 2012"/>
In 1966 Heller was founding editor of ''[[Management Today]]'', a monthly business magazine published by [[Haymarket Publishing]], where he worked for two decades. Here he started a second career as a writer of business books.<ref name="DB 2012"/>
== Publications == Heller wrote about 80 management books. A selection: * 1972. ''The Naked Manager'' * 1998. ''Essential Manager's Manual'' * 1999. ''Achieving Excellence'' * 2002. ''Manager's Handbook''
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == {{Wikiquote|Robert Heller}} * [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/sep/18/robert-heller Robert Heller obituary] at ''theguardian.com'' * [http://www.management-issues.com/robert-heller/ Articles of Robert Heller] at management-issues.com * [http://www.extensor.co.uk/articles/int_heller/interview_robert_heller.html Interview: Robert Heller] on extensor.co.uk, 2006
{{DEFAULTSORT:Heller, Robert}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:British business theorists]] [[Category:British male journalists]]

{{Infobox person | box_width = | name = Sir Ron Carter | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=NZL|ONZ|KNZM|size=100}} | image = File:Ron Carter ONZ (cropped).jpg | alt = | caption = Carter in 2016 | birth_name = Ronald Powell Carter | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1935|06|17|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Auckland]], New Zealand | death_date = | death_place = | religion = | other_names = | known_for = | alma_mater = [[University of Auckland]] | occupation = Civil engineer | organization = | parents = | spouse = Dianne Lewell Oxspring<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/10404035/Sir-Ron-Carter-humbled-by-top-honour | title=Sir Ron Carter humbled by top honour | work=Stuff | date=20 August 2014 | accessdate=18 March 2015 | author=Downes, Siobhan}}</ref> | children = | relatives = }} '''Sir Ronald Powell Carter''' {{post-nominals|country=NZL|ONZ|KNZM|size=85%}} (born 17 June 1935) is a retired New Zealand businessman.
==Early life and family== Carter was born in [[Auckland]] in 1935, the son of Sybil Muriel (née Townsend) and Eric Powell Carter, a mechanic.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NZH19350618.2.2.2 | title=Births | date=18 June 1935 | work=New Zealand Herald | accessdate=21 March 2015 | page=1 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title=Electoral District of Roskill: general roll of persons entitled to vote for Members of Parliament of New Zealand | year=1935 | page=39}}</ref> He was educated at [[Auckland Grammar School]] from 1948.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.ags.school.nz/our-community/news-and-messages/show/3455 | title=Sir Ron Carter visits Grammar | publisher=Auckland Grammar School | date=24 June 2014 | accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref> In 2013 he described his time at the school: "In all my days at school, although I was in a high-achieving class, I did not cross the platform once in my five years at Auckland Grammar to receive a class or a subject prize."<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10904676 | title=Realising your potential is key to success | work=NZ Herald | date=29 July 2013 | accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref>
Carter then attended [[University of Auckland|Auckland University College]], graduating in 1958 with a Master of Engineering degree in civil engineering.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://shadowsoftime.co.nz/university5.html |title=New Zealand university graduates 1870–1961: Ca–Cl |date= |website= |publisher= |accessdate=7 June 2014}}</ref> His thesis was titled ''The effect of stress on the longitudinal wave velocity of an ultrasonic pulse in concrete''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://librarysearch.auckland.ac.nz/primo_library/libweb/action/display.do?doc=uoa_alma21172310340002091 |title=Library search |date= |website= |publisher=University of Auckland |accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref>
==Beca Group== Carter joined the [[Beca Group|Beca]] engineering company in 1959, becoming a partner in 1965 and managing director in 1986.<ref name="SirPeter">{{cite web | url=http://www.sirpeterblaketrust.org/the-trust/our-people/sir-peter-blake-leadership-awards-selection-panel/sir-ron-carter-knzm-chair/ | title=Sir Ron Carter, KNZM (Chair) | publisher=Sir Peter Blake Trust | accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref> He was chairman of the Beca group until 2002.<ref name=stuff>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/industries/10109354/Highest-honour-for-call-me-Ron|title=Highest honour for 'call me Ron'|work=stuff.co.nz |accessdate=2 June 2014|date=2 June 2014}}</ref>
==Corporate governance and other roles== Carter has been a member, director or chairperson of many boards, including: * Founding chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority (1992–98)<ref name="Radionz">{{cite news | url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/246007/sir-ron-carter-receives-highest-honour | title=Sir Ron Carter receives highest honour | work=Radio New Zealand News | date=3 June 2014 | accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref> * National Infrastructure Advisory Board<ref name="RoyalCom">{{cite web | url=http://canterbury.royalcommission.govt.nz/About-the-Commissioners | title=About the Commissioners | publisher=Canterbury Earthquake Royal Commission | accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref> * Electricity Corporation of New Zealand<ref name="RoyalCom" /> * Association of Consulting Engineers New Zealand<ref name="RoyalCom" /> * Air New Zealand (1998–2007)<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nbr.co.nz/article/sir-ron-carter-retires-air-nz | title=Sir Ron Carter retires from Air NZ | work=NBR | date=27 February 2007 | accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref> * Trust Power Limited<ref name="SirPeter" /> * Aetna<ref name="SirPeter" /> * Sir Peter Blake Trust (until 2011)<ref name="SirPeter" /> * Chair of the Selection Panel for the Sir Peter Blake Leadership Awards<ref name="SirPeter" /> * Patron of the Committee For Auckland<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10721336 | title=Sir Ron Carter: Let's all get on board Waka Maori | work=NZ Herald | date=25 April 2011 | accessdate=17 March 2015 | author=Carter, Ron}}</ref> * Developed and co-founded the Iwi Business Consortium in 2009<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.ags.school.nz/our-community/news-and-messages/show/4509 | title=Korowai rewards for Sir Ron Carter's work | publisher=Auckland Grammar School | accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref> * Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Christchurch earthquakes<ref name="Radionz" /> * Independent representative to the Board of the 2011 Rugby World Cup<ref>{{cite news | url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/nz-s-highest-honour-came-blue-sir-ron-5988026 | title=NZ's highest honour 'came out of the blue' - Sir Ron | work=TVNZ | date=2 June 2014 | accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref> * Director Rural Equities Ltd.<ref name="BACS">{{cite web | url=http://bacshares.org.nz/2015/01/sir-ron-carter/ | title=Sir Ron Carter supports BACS | publisher=BACS | date=4 January 2015 | accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref>
==Honours== Carter was appointed a [[New Zealand Order of Merit|Knight Companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit]] for services to engineering and business administration in the [[1998 New Year Honours]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dpmc.govt.nz/node/395 |title=New Year honours list 1998 |date=31 December 1997 |publisher=Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet |accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref> and made a member of the [[Order of New Zealand]] in the [[2014 Birthday Honours (New Zealand)|2014 Queen's Birthday Honours]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/246007/sir-ron-carter-receives-highest-honour|title=Sir Ron Carter receives highest honour|work=Radio NZ |accessdate=2 June 2014|date=2 June 2014}}</ref>
In 2001, he was awarded an honorary [[Doctor of Engineering|doctorate in engineering]] by the [[University of Auckland]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.alumni.auckland.ac.nz/en/photo-galleries-and-video/distinguished-alumni-lectures-and-speeches/distinguished-alumni-speaker-series-2008-video/sir-ron-carter.html | title=Sir Ron Carter | publisher=University of Auckland | accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref>
Carter has also received the following honours: * 1997 – Distinguished Fellow of IPENZ 1997<ref name="SirPeter" /> * 2009 – Admitted to the Business Hall of Fame at the Auckland University Business School 2009<ref name="BACS" /> * 2010 – KEA World Class Leader for work in business and finance 2010<ref name="BACS" />
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.beca.co.nz/about_beca/history/hall_of_fame.aspx Ron Carter] at beca.co.nz
{{Order of New Zealand}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.comment: Deceased
revision.text:
'''Rudi Thomaes''' (21 August 1952 – 25 July 2018) was a [[Belgium|Belgian]] businessman and [[CEO]] of the [[Federation of Belgian Enterprises]] and a member of [[VOKA]].
==Education== He graduated as a bachelor of law from the [[University of Antwerp]] (UFSIA) and obtained a master's degree in law from the University of Antwerp (UIA).
==Career== He started his career as a ''Financial Export Coordinator'' at [[Alcatel-Lucent|Bell Telephone]] in 1976. He became Managing Director and Chairman of the Management Committee of Alcatel Bell in 1999. From 1979 until 1981 he was responsible for social, legal and fiscal affairs with [[ITT Corporation|ITT Industries]] in [[Belgium]]. In 1981 he returned to Bell Telephone as a contract lawyer until 1983, during this period he negotiated the joint venture and licence contract with China. From 1984 until 1986, he was Assistant Director and Head of the Export Treasury and International Contracts Department at Bell Telephone. From 1986 until 1988 he was Area Manager EMEA and responsible for the marketing of digital switching networks. From 1988 until 1998, he was General Counsel for [[Alcatel-Lucent|Alcatel]] Bell, and responsible for the legal department and the relations with the [[European Union]]. In 1997, he became responsible for the strategic change plan of Alcatel Bell. On 1 January 1999, he became Chief Operating Officer and on 1 October 1999 Chief Executive Officer and President of the Alcatel Bell Management Committee
From 2004 to 2012, Rudi Thomaes was CEO of the [[Federation of Belgian Enterprises]] and since 29 March 2005 he was a regent of the [[National Bank of Belgium]].
==Sources== * [http://www.ebsummit.org/cv_details.html?cvid=25 Rudi Thomaes] (European Business Summit] * [http://www.nbb.be/pub/01_00_00_00_00/01_02_00_00_00/01_02_04_00_00/Thomaes+Rudi.htm?l=en&t=ho Rudi Thomaes] (NBB)
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Thomaes, Rudi}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:Belgian businesspeople]] [[Category:University of Antwerp alumni]] {{Belgium-business-bio-stub}}

{{Infobox person |name = Salim Wardeh
سليم وردة |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Salim Aziz Wardeh |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1968|10|01}} |birth_place = [[Zahle]], [[Lebanon]] |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = [[Lebanese nationality law|Lebanese]] and [[Australian nationality law|Australian]] |other_names = |education = |employer = |occupation = |home_town = |title = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |term = |predecessor = [[Tammam Salam]] |successor = |party = [[Lebanese Forces]] |boards = |spouse = Nidal Hakim |partner = |children = Daughter: Macy Wardeh(1996) Son: Aziz Wardeh(1998) |parents = Aziz Wardeh
Yolande Estephanhttp://www.katagogi.com/Profile/Profile.aspx?l=EN&Nod=175351&fid=46273&PreveVal=7458|HWIBbbSLo4gfrJIpW7NKd8T4di+UNQuBha2to601rD0=|DDNp4ggZCaQqyvgoIPpw1g==1 |relatives = |signature = |website = www.salimwardy.com |footnotes = }} '''Salim Wardeh''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]: سليم وردة) (born October 1, 1968, in [[Zahle]], [[Lebanon]]) was the Minister of Culture in [[Lebanon]] until June 2011, when he was replaced by [[Gaby Layoun]].{{cite web |url=http://www.lebanonembassyus.org/country_lebanon/TheCabinet.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130414081913/http://www.lebanonembassyus.org/country_lebanon/TheCabinet.html |archivedate=2013-04-14 |df= }}http://www.infoplease.com/world/leaders/lebanon.html[http://www.kuna.net.kw/NewsAgenciesPublicSite/ArticleDetails.aspx?id=2173631&Language=en Lebanese PM finishes new gov''t line-up - Politics - Kuwait News Agency 13 June 2011][http://www.nowlebanon.com/NewsArticleDetails.aspx?ID=282682 Now Lebanon, 17 June 2011, Layoun says new cabinet will “confront STL”] Wardeh is a Catholic Christian and is a member of the [[Lebanese Forces]] which in turn is a member of the [[March 14 Alliance]]. Wardeh is a member of the board of directors of Tell Shiha Hospital. He also holds Australian citizenship. == Business career == He is the General Manager of Solifed,http://www.1stlebanon.net/lebanon/solifed.html a family business specializing in making wine that was founded in 1971 but dates back to 1893.{{cite web |url=http://www.domaine-wardy.com/aboutus.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021016205433/http://www.domaine-wardy.com/aboutus.html |archivedate=2002-10-16 |df= }}http://www.albaladonline.com/html/story.php?sid=83656{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == Personal life == He is married to Nidal Hakim and has two children Macy(1996) and Aziz(1998) == Miscellaneous == He underwent a failed kidnapping attempt in 1977. The kidnappers wanted to ask for ransom from Wardeh's wealthy business family.http://www.albaladonline.com/html/story.php?sid=83656{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == See also == * [[Lebanese government of November 2009]] * [[Lebanese Forces]] * [[March 14 Alliance]] * [[Lebanese Christians]] * [[Lebanese Australians]] * [[List of Lebanese people]] * [[Lebanese wine]] == References == == Notes == Alternative transliterations used in the media: Warde, Wardy. == External links == * [http://www.domaine-wardy.com Official website of Solifed] * [http://www.1stlebanon.net/lebanon/solifed.html Solifed's profile on 1st Lebanon] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{Succession box |title = Minister of Culture |before = Tammam Salam |after = Gabi Lyon |years = 09 November 2009 - June 2011{{spaced ndash}} }} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wardeh, Salim}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:People from Zahle]] [[Category:Government ministers of Lebanon]] [[Category:Lebanese Forces politicians]] [[Category:Lebanese businesspeople]] [[Category:Lebanese winemakers]] [[Category:Lebanese Christians]] [[Category:Lebanese Melkite Greek Catholics]] [[Category:Australian people of Lebanese descent]]

'''Samuel Paul Garner''' (Aug. 15, 1910 - Oct. 16, 1996) was an American accounting scholar, and Professor at the [[University of Alabama]], known for his work "Evolution of cost accounting to 1925."<ref>Burchell, Stuart, et al. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20150218033523/http://econ3.upm.edu.my/kelasmaya/sumberkursus/JPK00015/ACT2112/Roles%20of%20accounting%20in%20organizations%20and%20society.pdf The roles of accounting in organizations and society]." ''Accounting, Organizations and Society'' 5.1 (1980): 5-27.</ref><ref>[[Abbott, Andrew]]. ''The system of professions: An essay on the division of expert labor.'' University of Chicago Press, 2014.</ref>
== Biography == Born in [[Yadkinville, North Carolina]] to Samuel W. and Ila Jane (Hoots) Garner, Garner at [[Duke University]] obtained his AB in 1932, and his AM in 1934.<ref name="WiWiA 1980">Who’s Who in America, 1980.</ref> He then moved to the [[University of Texas at Austin]] where he obtained his PhD in 1940 under supervision of [[George Hillis Newlove]].<ref name="PS 1997">[[Previts, Gary John]], and William D. Samson. "In Memoriam: S. Paul Garner: Accountancy's Ambassador to the World." ''The Accounting Historians Journal'' 24.2 (1997): 153.</ref> He was awarded an honorary degree by the [[Pusan National University]], and by the [[University of Alabama]] in 1971.<ref name="WiWiA 1980"/>
After his graduation in 1939 Garner joined the Culverhouse School of Accountancy at the [[University of Alabama]], where he would serve his entire academic career. He started out as faculty member, and was Dean of the College of Business from 1954 to 1971. He was consultant to the US [[United States Department of Education|Department of Education]], to the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] and for the [[United States Department of State|Department of State]] he conducted educational research in South America, Europe, Africa, and Asia.<ref name="WiWiA 1980"/> Garner was President of the [[American Accounting Association]] in 1951-52, and also served as President of the [[American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business]] in 1964-65.<ref name="PS 1997"/>
Garner is characterized as "perhaps the last of the leaders of an age when the academic and professional community were driven to new levels of size and activity during the economic expansion of the post World War II period."<ref name="PS 1997"/>
== Selected publications == * [[Newlove, George Hillis]], and Samuel Paul Garner. ''Elementary Cost Accounting.'' Heath, 1949. * [[Newlove, George Hillis]], and Samuel Paul Garner. ''[http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/007908723 Advanced Accounting].'' Vol. 1. Heath, 1951. * Garner, Samuel Paul. ''Evolution of cost accounting to 1925.'' Vol. 1. University of Alabama Press, 1976.
Articles, a selection: * Garner, Samuel Paul. "Has cost accounting come of age." ''NACA Bulletin'' (November) (1951): 287-292.
== References == {{reflist|2}}

'''Steam exploded fiber''' is a [[pulping]] and extraction technique that has been applied to [[wood]] and other fibrous organic material.<ref name="Avella 1995">{{cite journal|author=Maurizio Avella|author2=Claudio Bozzi |author3=Ramiro dell'Erba |author4=Bonaventura Focher |author5=Annamaria Marzetti |author6=Ezio Martuscelli |title=Steam-exploded wheat straw fibers as reinforcing material for polypropylene-based composites. Characterization and properties|date= November 1995|journal=Die Angewandte makromolekulare Chemie: Applied macromolecular chemistry and physics|volume=233|issue=1|pages= 149–166|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NckXAAAAIAAJ|accessdate=29 November 2011|publisher=Hüthig & Wepf Verlag}}</ref> The resulting fibers can be combined with organic polymers to produce fiber [[composite material]]s. Alternatively, the fibers, along with other extracted substances, can be processed chemically or digested to produce [[ethanol]] and other useful substances.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://aiche.confex.com/aiche/2005/techprogram/P29158.HTM Processing corn cobs to ethanol and other chemicals] * [http://www.ornl.gov/sci/bst/symposium/index_files/6Aabstracts/6A_19.htm Insitu Detoxification Cotton Gin Waste for Ethanol Production] * [http://www.geocities.co.jp/Technopolis/3755/abstracts.htm#Holts1 Binderless boards from steam-exploded oil palm pulp]
[[Category:Industrial processes]] [[Category:Pulp and paper industry]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}} {{Use British English|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix=[[The Right Honourable]] |name=The Viscount Astor |image = Official portrait of Viscount Astor.jpg |office1 = [[Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport|Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for National Heritage]] |primeminister1 = [[John Major]] |term_start1 = 20 July 1994 |term_end1 = 6 July 1995 |predecessor1 = [[Iain Sproat]] |successor1 = [[Richard Fletcher-Vane, 2nd Baron Inglewood|The Lord Inglewood]] |office2 = [[Department for Health and Social Security|Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Health and Social Security]] |primeminister2 = [[John Major]] |term_start2 = 16 September 1993 |term_end2 = 20 July 1994 |predecessor2 = [[Ann Widdecombe]] |successor2 = [[James Arbuthnot]] |office3 = [[Lord-in-waiting]]
[[Government Whip]] |primeminister3 = [[Margaret Thatcher]]
[[John Major]] |term_start3 = 11 October 1990 |term_end3 = 16 September 1993 |predecessor3 = [[Hugh Cavendish, Baron Cavendish of Furness|The Lord Cavendish of Furness]] |successor3 = [[John MacKay, Baron MacKay of Ardbrecknish|The Lord MacKay of Ardbrecknish]] |office4 = [[Member of the House of Lords]]
[[Lord Temporal]] |term_start4 = 24 July 1973
[[Hereditary peer|Hereditary Peerage]] |term_end4 = |predecessor4 = [[William Astor, 3rd Viscount Astor]] |successor4 = |birth_name=William Waldorf Astor III |birth_date={{birth date and age|1951|12|27|df=y}} |party = [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] |spouse={{marriage|[[Annabel Astor, Viscountess Astor|Annabel Jones]]|1976}} |alma_mater=[[Eton College]] |parents=[[William Astor, 3rd Viscount Astor]]
[[Sarah Baring|Sarah Norton]] |children=3 |relatives= See [[Astor family]] |occupation= politician, businessman }} '''William Waldorf Astor III, 4th Viscount Astor''' (born 27 December 1951) is an English businessman and politician who sits as a [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[hereditary peer|hereditary]] [[Lord Temporal]] in the [[House of Lords]]. He is a member of the [[Astor family]] known for its prominence in business, society, and politics in both the United States and the United Kingdom. ==Biography== William Waldorf III is the son of [[William Astor, 3rd Viscount Astor]] (1907–1966) and [[Sarah Baring|Sarah Kathleen Elinor Norton]] (1920–2013). From his father's later marriages, he has three younger half-sisters: Emily (born 1956), Janet (born 1961), and Pauline (born 1964). From his mother's remarriage to Thomas Michael Baring, he has a younger half-brother named Edward Richard Philip Baring (born September 1962).http://thepeerage.com/p7900.htm#i78996 He was educated at [[Eton College]]. Astor was a [[Lord-in-waiting]] (a House of Lords whip) from 1990 to 1993. He was then made a [[Parliamentary Under Secretary of State]] at the [[Department of Social Security]]. In 1994, he moved to the [[Department of National Heritage]] where he served until leaving the government in 1995.[http://thepeerage.com/p7535.htm thePeerage.com - Person Page 7535] He was a member of the Founding Council of the [[Rothermere American Institute]] at the [[University of Oxford]].{{cite web|title=Founding Council {{!}} The Rothermere American Institute|url=http://www.rai.ox.ac.uk/about/history/foundingcouncil|publisher=Rothermere American Institute|accessdate=2012-11-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121117021312/http://www.rai.ox.ac.uk/about/history/foundingcouncil|archivedate=17 November 2012|df=dmy-all}} Viscount Astor is Chairman of [[Silvergate Media]] and director of Networkers Plc (since 2007) and trustee of Stanley Spencer Gallery in Cookham. ==Marriage and children== Astor married [[Annabel Astor, Viscountess Astor|Annabel Lucy Veronica Jones]] (born 1948), daughter of Timothy Angus Jones and Patricia David Pandora Clifford on 14 January 1976. They have three children: * [[The Honourable|Hon]] Flora Katherine Astor (born 7 June 1976) * Hon William Waldorf "Will" Astor IV (born 18 January 1979) * Hon James Jacob Astor (born 1981) The heir to the viscountcy is his elder son, Will, who married model Lohralee Stutz, daughter of Serge Alain Stutz and Lerma Villas, at [[East Hendred]], [[Oxfordshire]] on 5 September 2009. They have a son William Waldorf Astor V (born 4 May 2012) and a daughter Allegra Annabel Astor (born 14 August 2013).{{cite web|title=Allegra Annabel Astor Birth Announcement|url=http://announcements.thetimes.co.uk/celebration/timesonline-uk/celebrations-announcement.aspx?n=allegra-annabel-astor&aid=166536886|publisher=The Times|date=21 August 2013}} His wife Annabel's stepfather was his uncle [[Michael Astor|Michael Langhorne Astor]]. Viscountess Astor was previously married to [[Sir Reginald Sheffield, 8th Baronet]] by whom she is the mother of [[Samantha Cameron]], wife of former [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[David Cameron]]. ==Arms== {{Infobox COA wide |image = [[File:Viscount Coronet.svg|center|100px]]
[[File:Blasón del Vizcondado Astor.svg|center|100px]] |crest = From a Mount Vert a Falcon rising proper ensigned by three Mullets Gold |coronet = A [[Coronet|Coronet of a Viscount]] |escutcheon = Or a Falcon resting on a Dexter Hand couped at the wrist proper gauntleted Gules in chief two Fleur-de-lys of the last |supporters = Dexter: a North American Indian; Sinister: a North American fur trapper; each habited accoutred and holding in the exterior hand a Rifle all proper |motto = Ad Astra (To the stars) }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{UK Peer links | parliament = lords/member/3429 | hansardcurr = 3812 | guardian = | publicwhip = Viscount_Astor | theywork = viscount_astor | record = | bbc = 26719.stm | journalisted = }} *{{Hansard-contribs | mr-william-astor | the Viscount Astor }} * http://www.thepeerage.com/p7535.htm#i75348 {{s-start}} {{s-reg|uk}} {{s-bef | before = [[William Astor, 3rd Viscount Astor|William Waldorf Astor II]]}} {{s-ttl | title = [[Viscount Astor]] | years = 1966–present}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}} {{British viscounts}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Astor, William Astor, 4th Viscount}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:English people of German descent]] [[Category:English people of Irish descent]] [[Category:English people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:Astor family|William]] [[Category:Livingston family]] [[Category:Conservative Party (UK) Baronesses- and Lords-in-Waiting]] [[Category:Hereditary peers elected under the House of Lords Act]] [[Category:People educated at Eton College]] [[Category:Viscounts in the Peerage of the United Kingdom]]

{{Infobox Lt Governor |name= William Lowther Jackson |image= William Lowther Jackson.jpg |order= 3rd |office= Lieutenant Governor of Virginia |term_start= December 7, 1857 |term_end= January 1, 1860 |governor= [[Henry A. Wise]] |predecessor= [[Elisha W. McComas]] |successor= [[Robert Latane Montague]] |birth_date= February 3, 1825 |birth_place= [[Clarksburg, West Virginia|Clarksburg]], [[Virginia]], U.S. (now [[West Virginia]]) |death_date= {{Death date and age|1890|3|26|1825|2|3}} |death_place= [[Louisville, Kentucky]], U.S. |placeofburial= [[Cave Hill Cemetery]], Louisville, Kentucky |placeofburial_label= Place of burial |spouse= Sarah Elizabeth Jackson
(''nee'' Creel) |alma_mater= |profession= Attorney, judge, soldier |party= [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] |religion= |allegiance= [[Confederate States]] |branch= [[Confederate States Army]] |serviceyears= 1861–1865 |rank= [[File:Confederate States of America General.png|35px]] [[General officers in the Confederate States Army#Brigadier general|Brigadier General]] |unit= |commands= [[31st Virginia Infantry]]
[[19th Virginia Cavalry]]
W.L. Jackson's Cavalry Brigade |battles= [[American Civil War]] *[[Battle of Rich Mountain]] *[[Battle of Cheat Mountain]] *[[Jackson's Valley Campaign|Valley Campaign of 1862]] *[[Seven Days Battles]] *[[Second Battle of Manassas]] *[[Battle of Sharpsburg]] *[[Battle of Fredericksburg]] *[[Jones-Imboden Raid]] *[[Battle of Bulltown]] *[[Battle of Cloyd's Mountain]] *[[Valley Campaigns of 1864]] }} '''William Lowther Jackson Jr.''' (February 3, 1825 – March 26, 1890) was an American politician and jurist who served as [[Lieutenant Governor of Virginia]] prior to the [[American Civil War]], and later served as a general in the [[Confederate States Army]]. ==Early life== ===Paternal ancestry=== William L. Jackson was a cousin of [[Stonewall Jackson|Thomas J. "Stonewall" Jackson]] through their great-grandparents, John Jackson (1715 or 1719 – 1801) and Elizabeth Cummins (also known as Elizabeth Comings and Elizabeth Needles) (1723–1828). John Jackson was a Protestant (Ulster-Scottish) from [[Coleraine]], [[County Londonderry]], Ireland. While living in London, England, he was convicted of the capital crime of larceny for stealing £170; the judge at the [[Old Bailey]] sentenced him to seven years of [[Indentured servitude in the Americas|indentured servitude in America]]. Elizabeth, a strong, blonde woman over {{convert|6|ft|cm}} tall, born in London, England was also convicted of larceny in an unrelated case for stealing 19 pieces of silver, jewelry, and fine lace, and received a similar sentence. They both were transported on the prison ship ''Litchfield'', which departed London in May 1749 with 150 convicts. John and Elizabeth met on board and were in love by the time the ship arrived at [[Annapolis, Maryland]]. Although they were sent to different locations in Maryland for their indentures, the couple married in July 1755.Robertson, 1997, pp. 1–2 The family migrated west across the [[Blue Ridge Mountains]] to settle near [[Moorefield, West Virginia|Moorefield, Virginia]] (now [[West Virginia]]) in 1758. In 1770, they moved farther west to the [[Tygart Valley River|Tygart Valley]]. They began to acquire large parcels of virgin farming land near the present-day town of [[Buckhannon, West Virginia|Buckhannon]], including 3,000 acres (12 km²) in Elizabeth's name. John and his two teenage sons, were early recruits for the [[American Revolutionary War]], fighting in the [[Battle of Kings Mountain]] on October 7, 1780; John finished the war as [[Captain (OF-2)|captain]] and served as a [[lieutenant]] of the [[Virginia militia]] after 1787. While the men were in the Army, Elizabeth converted their home to a haven, "Jackson's Fort," for refugees from Indian attacks.Robertson, 1997, pp. 2–3. John and Elizabeth had eight children. Their eldest son, [[George Jackson (Virginia politician)|George Jackson]] (1757–1831), was a colonel in the [[Virginia militia]] during the [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]] and [[United States House of Representatives|Congressman]] from Virginia. George and his wife, Elizabeth Brake (1757–1812), daughter of Jacob and Mary E. (née Cooper) Brake, had three children; their youngest was William's father, William Lowther Jackson Sr. (1798–1836), who also served in the Virginia militia. ===Childhood and prewar career=== Jackson was born on February 3, 1825 in [[Clarksburg, West Virginia|Clarksburg, Virginia]] (now West Virginia). Studying law he was admitted to the Bar of Virginia in 1847.{{cite web|last1=Wickline|first1=John|title=The Other Gen. Jackson: William Lowther 'Mudwall' Jackson|url=http://www.connect-clarksburg.com/connect.cfm?func=view§ion=Famous-People&item=The-Other-Gen-Jackson-William-Lowther-Mudwall-Jackson-2849|website=Connect-Clarksburg|accessdate=16 August 2015}} He married Sarah Elizabeth Creel on December 19, 1849, and together they had two or three children. Jackson was a big man, standing about six feet tall and weighing about 200 pounds. He had a shock of dark red hair and piercing blue eyes like those of his famous cousin, Thomas Jackson. William Jackson was not known as an eloquent speaker, but he was known as a forceful one.{{cite web|last1=Wittenberg|first1=Eric J.|title=Brig. Gen. William L. "Mudwall" Jackson|url=http://civilwarcavalry.com/?p=2962|website=Rantings of a Civil War Historian|accessdate=16 August 2015}} He later became the [[Commonwealth's Attorney]] for [[Harrison County, West Virginia|Harrison County]]. Entering politics he was elected into the [[Virginia House of Delegates]] two times, also serving as Second Auditor of the State and as superintendent of the state library fund. Jackson was the third [[Lieutenant Governor of Virginia]] from 1857 until 1860 and afterwards was made a circuit judge in the 19th district.Evans, 2004, p. 131 ==Civil War== [[File:William L. Jackson.jpg|thumb|left|Jackson during the civil war.]] When the civil war erupted Jackson, a proponent of slavery, resigned from his position as judge and enlisted in the [[Confederate States Army]] as a Private. Recommended to General [[Robert E. Lee]] he quickly was promoted to Lieutenant Colonel of the [[31st Virginia Infantry|31st Virginia Infantry Regiment]]. Assigned to the command of Gen. [[Robert S. Garnett]] he participated in the [[Western Virginia Campaign]] and the battles of [[Battle of Rich Mountain|Rich Mountain]] and [[Battle of Cheat Mountain|Cheat Mountain]]. In July 1861 he was promoted to rank of Colonel. In early 1862 he became a Volunteer [[Aide-de-camp]] to his cousin, Maj. Gen. [[Stonewall Jackson|Thomas J. Jackson]]; and participated in his campaigns during the year.{{cite web|last1=Webb|first1=Kerry|title=Jackson, William Lowther "Mudwall"|url=http://grapevine.com.au/~kwebb/cong_j.html|website=Confederate Generals - J|accessdate=16 August 2015}}Eicher, 2001, p. 317 William's younger brother George, who was a graduate of [[West Point]] (Class of 1856) and served in the U.S. Army, became a colonel in the Confederate Army, too. In February 1863 William Jackson was authorized to organize a mounted regiment for service behind the enemy lines and he raised the [[19th Virginia Cavalry]]. His regiment immediately joined the [[Jones-Imboden Raid]], first under command of [[Albert G. Jenkins]], then under [[John D. Imboden]]. Jackson stayed in western Virginia, being assigned to command a cavalry brigade. He fought at the [[Battle of Bulltown|Bulltown]] and confronted [[George Crook]]'s Union Army on its return into West Virginia following Crook's victory at the [[Battle of Cloyd's Mountain]]. In 1864 he joined Lt. Gen. [[Jubal Early]] in the [[Valley Campaigns of 1864|Valley Campaigns]] from May to October. He received his promotion to brigadier general on December 19, 1864. On April 15, 1865, six days after Gen. Lee surrendered the [[Army of Northern Virginia]] at [[Battle of Appomattox Court House|Appomattox Court House]], he disbanded his brigade. Refusing to surrender, he headed westwards, finally getting a parole in [[Brownsville, Texas]], on July 26, 1865. ==Later life== Temporarily emigrating to Mexico, he returned to what was now [[Western Virginia]] just to learn that former Confederate officers were barred from practicing law in the state. He then moved to [[Louisville, Kentucky]], where he was allowed to resume his practice of law. Jackson became a circuit judge again and kept this position for his remaining life. He died on March 26, 1890 of [[Bright's disease]] in Louisville; and was interred there on [[Cave Hill Cemetery]]. ==Nickname controversy== William L. Jackson is one of three Confederate generals associated with the nickname "Mudwall", a reference to the "Stonewall" nickname given to his cousin Thomas. While William Jackson has been known as such for a long time, it was found by noted historian Garry W. Gallagher that the nickname was originally given to fellow Confederate General [[Alfred E. Jackson]] from Tennessee (no family relation). It seems the two were mixed up in the [[Southern Historical Society Papers]] in 1906 and the error was involuntarily repeated afterwards. Sometimes the name is even attributed to another (likewise not related) Confederate Brigadier, [[John K. Jackson]]. It is also possible that at times the name was attributed to several of the Jacksons simultaneously.{{cite web|title=You Know of " Old Stonewall " Meet " Old Mudwall " Jackson|url=http://civilwartalk.com/threads/you-know-of-old-stonewall-meet-old-mudwall-jackson.74415/|website=Civil War Talk|accessdate=16 August 2015}}Walden, 1990 ==See also== {{Portal|American Civil War|Biography}} *[[Alfred E. Jackson]] *[[List of American Civil War generals (Confederate)]] *[[Stonewall Jackson]] *[[Virginia in the American Civil War]] *[[West Virginia in the American Civil War]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * Eicher, John H., and [[David J. Eicher]], ''Civil War High Commands.'' Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2001. {{ISBN|978-0-8047-3641-1}}. * [[Clement A. Evans|Evans, Clement A.]], ed. [https://archive.org/search.php?query=publisher%3A%22Confederate%20Pub.%20Co.%22 ''Confederate Military History: A Library of Confederate States History'']. 12 vols. Atlanta: Confederate Publishing Company, 1899. {{OCLC|833588}}. Retrieved January 20, 2011. Volume 2. Johnson, B. T.; Maryland. White, Robert; West Virginia. Online version: Evans, Clement A. (Clement Anselm), 1833–1911. Confederate military history. Atlanta, Ga., Confederate Pub. Co., 1899. (OCoLC)560915765. * [[James I. Robertson Jr.|Robertson, James I. Jr.]] ''Stonewall Jackson: The Man, The Soldier, The Legend''. New York: Simon & Schuster Macmillan, 1997. {{ISBN|978-0-02-864685-5}}. * Sifakis, Stewart. ''Who Was Who in the Civil War.'' New York: Facts On File, 1988. {{ISBN|978-0-8160-1055-4}}. * Walden, Geoffrey R. (1990). "Will the Real "Mudwall" Jackson Please Stand Up?". ''Blue & Gray'' VIII (#1). * [[Ezra J. Warner (historian)|Warner, Ezra J.]] ''Generals in Gray: Lives of the Confederate Commanders.'' Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1959. {{ISBN|978-0-8071-0823-9}}. ==Bibliography== *Hardway, Ronald V.; ''On Our Own Soil: William Lowther Jackson and the Civil War in West Virginia's Mountains''; Quarrier Press, Charleston WV; October 3, 2003; {{ISBN|978-1-891852-27-5}} ==External links== *[http://www.bluegraymagazine.com/Files/mudwall%20jackson.pdf Will the Real "Mudwall" Please Stand Up? (pdf)] *{{findagrave|8927}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{Succession box | title=[[List of Lieutenant Governors of Virginia|Lieutenant Governor of Virginia]] | before=[[Elisha W. McComas]] | after=[[Robert Latane Montague|Robert L. Montague]] | years=1857–1860 }} {{S-end}} {{VALtGovernors}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jackson, William Lowther Mudwall}} [[Category:Confederate States Army brigadier generals]] [[Category:1825 births]] [[Category:1890 deaths]] [[Category:Lieutenant Governors of Virginia]] [[Category:Politicians from Clarksburg, West Virginia]] [[Category:Jackson family of West Virginia]] [[Category:Virginia Democrats]] [[Category:People of Virginia in the American Civil War]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | name = Yury Kovalchuk | caption = | birth_name = Yury Valentinovich Kovalchuk | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1951|07|25|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Leningrad]], [[Soviet Union]] (now St Petersburg, Russia) | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = | education = | alma mater = | occupation = Chairman and largest shareholder, [[Rossiya Bank]] | known for = "Putin's personal banker" | salary = | networth = $1.9 billion | spouse = | parents = | children = | relatives = [[Mikhail Kovalchuk]] (brother) | website = |awards = {{plainlist | * [[File:Orden of Friendship.png|25px]] [[Order of Friendship]] }} }}
'''Yury Valentinovich Kovalchuk''' ({{lang-ru|Юрий Валентинович Ковальчук}}, born 25 July 1951) is a Russian [[billionaire]] businessman and financier who is "reputed to be [[Vladimir Putin]]'s personal banker".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rfe.rferl.org/newsline/2008/03/1-RUS/rus-070308.asp|title=Russians make leap forward on global billionaires' list|publisher=[[Radio Liberty]]|date=7 March 2008|accessdate=10 May 2008}}</ref> The May 2008 issue of Russian ''[[Forbes]]'' listed him for the first time in its ''Golden Hundred'' of Russia's richest, calling him and another new entrant to the ''List'', [[Gennady Timchenko]], "good acquaintances of Vladimir Putin."<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/sphereNews/idUSL234792120080423?sp=true&view=sphere Kremlin-linked tycoon eyes Russia media firm-report] [[Reuters|reuters.com]] 23 April 2008.</ref> The magazine placed him at number 53 on the Russians-only list, with an estimated fortune of $1.9 billion. After sanctions imposed on Kovalchuk in 2018, this dropped to $650 million.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://themoscowtimes.com/articles/russia-loses-23-billionaires-to-economic-crisis-45833|title=Russia Loses 23 Billionaires to Economic Crisis|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en}}</ref>
From 1987 to 1991 he was the first deputy director of [[Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute]]. Since 2004 he has been chair of [[Rossiya Bank]] and its largest shareholder.<ref>[http://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/article.shtml?2005/03/01/88331 Anna Shcherbakova. Interview with Mikhail Klishin, Director general of the Russia Bank.] [[Vedomosti]] #35(1316), 1 March 2005. (in Russian)</ref><ref>[http://www.anticompromat.ru/oligarhi/ppo.html The Origin of Putin's Oligarchy] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071222000000/http://www.anticompromat.ru/oligarhi/ppo.html |date=22 December 2007 }} by Vladimir Pribylovsky. Ms., 11 October 2005. (in Russian)</ref><ref>[https://archive.is/20080515233652/http://www.stockmap.spb.ru/company/3022/0/ The Russia Bank], Stockmap.spb.ru</ref>
Since the early 1990s Kovalchuk has owned a [[dacha]] in Solovyovka in the [[Priozersky District]] of the [[Leningrad Oblast|Leningrad region]], located on the eastern shore of the Komsomolskoye lake on the [[Karelian Isthmus]] near St. Petersburg. His neighbours there are [[Vladimir Putin]], [[Vladimir Yakunin]], [[Andrei Aleksandrovich Fursenko|Andrei Fursenko]], [[Sergey Fursenko]], [[Viktor Myachin]], [[Vladimir Smirnov (businessman)|Vladimir Smirnov]] and [[Nikolay Shamalov]]. Together they instituted the co-operative society [[Ozero]] (the Lake) which united their properties on 10 November 1996.<ref>[https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2013/02/how-the-1980s-explains-vladimir-putin/273135/# How the 1980s Explains Vladimir Putin. ''The Ozero group.''] By Fiona Hill & Clifford G. Gaddy, ''The Atlantic'', 14 February 2013</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.ru/HISTORY/FELSHTINSKY/naslednik.txt|title=Владимир Прибыловский, Юрий Фельштинский. Операция "Наследник". Главы из книги|author=|date=|website=www.lib.ru|accessdate=22 November 2018}}</ref> [https://web.archive.org/web/20070109131958/http://anticompromat.ru/oligarhi/ppo.html]
His elder brother [[Mikhail Kovalchuk]] is the scientific secretary of the Council for Science and High Technologies attached to the president of the [[Russian Federation]].
In 2015 Yury Kovalchuk's National Media Group (NMG) and US Discovery channel joined forces to form Media Alliance of which NMG owns 80% <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://themoscowtimes.com/articles/billionaire-kovalchuks-national-media-group-to-buy-russian-distributor-of-cnn-51323|title=Billionaire Kovalchuk's National Media Group to Buy Russian Distributor of CNN|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en}}</ref>. Later that year, Kovalchuk acquired the rights to Ted Turner’s Russian assets including the Russian version of CNN, Cartoon Network and Boomerang. The reason for the sale was based on the Russian media ownership law that limits ownership of Russian media by foreigners. <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.eurasianbusinessbriefing.com/billionaire-kovalchuk/|title=‘Putin’s personal banker’ Kovalchuk to buy CNN Russia as Turner moves out|date=2015-12-24|work=Eurasian Business Briefing - Information for Investors|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
In 2017 Kovalchuk purchased the century-old Novy Svet vineyard in the Crimean Peninsula for $26.4 million in one of the first privatization deals in the region since the annexation of the region by Russia. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://themoscowtimes.com/news/putin-ally-targeted-by-us-sanctions-buys-winery-in-crimea-60001|title=Putin Ally Targeted by U.S. Sanctions Buys Winery in Crimea|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en}}</ref>
==Sanctions== Kovalchuk was one of several individuals sanctioned by the U.S. Treasury Department on 20 March 2014 in response to the [[2014 Crimean crisis]]. According to the [[United States Department of the Treasury|U.S. Treasury]], Kovalchuk is a close advisor to President Putin and has been referred to as one of his “cashiers.”<ref>{{Cite web|title=Executive Order - Blocking Property of Additional Persons Contributing to the Situation in Ukraine |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/03/20/executive-order-blocking-property-additional-persons-contributing-situat |publisher=The White House - Office of the Press Secretary}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/OFAC-Enforcement/Pages/20140320_33.aspx|title=Ukraine-related Designations|author=|date=|website=www.treasury.gov|accessdate=22 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/SDN-List/Pages/default.aspx|title=Specially Designated Nationals And Blocked Persons List (SDN) Human Readable Lists|author=|date=|website=www.treasury.gov|accessdate=22 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Treasury Sanctions Russian Officials, Members Of The Russian Leadership’s Inner Circle, And An Entity For Involvement In The Situation In Ukraine |url=http://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Pages/jl23331.aspx |work= |publisher= United States Treasury Department |date=20 March 2014 |accessdate=20 March 2014}}</ref><ref name=Sanctions>{{cite web|last=Shuklin |first=Peter |title=Putin's inner circle: who got in a new list of US sanctions |url=https://news.liga.net/articles/politics/1066761-blizhniy_krug_putina_kto_popal_v_novyy_spisok_sanktsiy_ssha.htm |publisher=liga.net |date=21 March 2014 |accessdate=20 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207152258/http://news.liga.net/articles/politics/1066761-blizhniy_krug_putina_kto_popal_v_novyy_spisok_sanktsiy_ssha.htm |archivedate=7 February 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref name=Ukraine-EO13661>{{cite web | last = President of The United States | title = Ukraine EO13661 | url = https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Programs/Documents/ukraine_eo2.pdf | publisher = Federal Register | date = 19 March 2016 | accessdate = 20 February 2016}}</ref>
Kovalchuk is a known friend of Putin’ he hosted the wedding of Putin’s daughter Katerina Tikhonova to Kirill Shamalov at his wholly owned ski resort, Igora, in 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/russia-capitalism-shamalov/|title=The man who married Putin's daughter and then made a fortune|website=Reuters|language=en|access-date=2018-11-22}}</ref>
